content: I would use this card, I am currently using one similar to it sponsored by WalMart. And I must admit that it is a very convenient and safe way to manage my digital transactions. I would recommend this card to anyone.

I am not impressed with the information I have read on the Platinum Card from American Express. The fact that the balance has to be paid in full every month does not give very much flexibility. For example, if I was having a rough month financially and could only afford to pay $50 toward the balance, I would not have that luxury, as I would with other cards. I also was bothered by the $450 annual fee! If you are paying off your balance in full every month, I do not think it is feasible to charge such an outrageous annual fee! On the other hand, if you enjoy earning rewards, this seems to have a pretty substantial reward program but I still do not feel that the $450 annual fee is justified by the rewards you may earn.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The American Express Serve Card is an interesting offer for a pre-paid credit account. There is no activation fee and the monthly fee is only a dollar. There is no credit check, no minimum balance, and no hidden fees. The card gives you $50.00 credit after two $250.00 direct deposit payments. You are able to load funds on the account at CVS Stores and 7-11 Stores. There is a mobile app. that is available to you to manage your account, pay bills, etc. The American Express Serve Card is a good value for the prepaid consumer.

The Hilton Credit Card has very attractive terms. The most surprising is that there is no annual fee. The range of interest rates is a little steep, however not unreasonable. The rates are competitive to other similar offers. The Hilton Credit Card also offers cardholders some pretty nice reward points toward future stays with no blackout dates. This is a really nice perk for business or personal frequent travelers. The card also offers baggage insurance which is essential in today's world. The Hilton Credit Card is a really smart offer.

The complimentary Amazon Prime offer makes the Blue Cash Everyday Card from American Express a winner. As if that wasn't enough, you also get 3 percent back at U.S supermarkets. No other card I know of gives you such outstanding benefits.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: At first glance, this seems like a great card. The Amazon prime sounds fantastic - however, buying it on your own only costs $79 - and this card has a $75 annual fee. So that doesn't really count in your first year. That leaves the $100 initial bonus, not bad, and the 0% intro rate is nice. You could use it to take advantage of a big purchase you plan to pay back slowly. Overall, American Express is known for great customer service. This is better than store cards (not saying much) but worse than many other credit cards out there.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The first thing I liked about this card is the $50 free with a 250$ direct deposit. Most other card companies give you about 1% cash back and that totals to be $5000 in purchases before you see the $50. With the American Express Serve card, it is well worth the dollar monthly fee to be using a pre-paid card with a company I can trust. It is easy to load money onto the card, just make sure you avoid the ATMs with fees!

This is not a bad card compared to other credit cards, but it is also not the best. It is a mediocre card that will work for someone who does not care much about rewards. The interest rate is a little better than most. The Hilton credit card is for those who do a lot of traveling, so keep that in mind before applying for this. Based on what I have used before, I would give this card a 4 out of 5 rating.

Okay I just love the fact that I can use my credit card to buy things which I already do and then the end result is not just less money in my pocket but I can then after 7.500 pts actually get $100 off my next airline trip. Fiji here I come !!! I use other credit cards like JC Penney's, Visa rewards etc. but this one is really cool if you are a traveler. It is really neat you get one pt for every dollar you spend. If you are a traveler then you need to look into this card.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: Target Prepaid credit card is a risk I don't want to take even if it is through American Express. The hacking episode Target had a couple months ago probably could not have been avoided. Reading the news about the cyber attack makes it look like the company did all they could to protect consumers. Still, I would be very unlikely to give anything having to do with Target and credit another chance.
I can't log in to my account it has been over a month since I set it up and I can't login.

The American Express Gold card is an excellent option for those with problematic credit history who would like to rebuild their credit. While I think a $125 annual fee is a bit steep, it's quite average for all cards that compete in this area. The other downfall is having to pay off your balance in full every month. The point rewards are a great incentive though to get more bang for your buck while improving your credit score!

I do not like the fact that the card has to be paid in full each month. I feel as though this means the time I am actually able to use my "credit" with this card will be an average of 2 weeks and that is not long enough to me. With other types of cards, there is much more flexibility in determing my pay-back schedule.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The green card for businesses from American Express is a very good card since it provides additional services to the traveller. Although American Express is not accepted everywhere, it is easy to manage and one of its great advantages is that it is easy to replace if it is lost. Additionally, Amex offers some emergency services to the business travellers.
department: Business Green Rewards Card from American Express

content: The Blue Cash Everyday Card is awesome. Plain and simple. There are so many nice surprises that this card offers. For example, the $50 sign up reward money if you spend a grand within the first three months and the complementary Amazon Prime account are just a few of the great rewards for signing up with this card. One of the great features of this card that I found to be a great annoyance with my old Visa was the foreign transaction fee rate. At only 2.7%, the foreign transaction fee is nearly half of my card, and that makes a big difference when you are vacationing and money is spent faster than normal. Again, an awesome card.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: We have been incredibly pleased with this card. I have never had a fee-based card, but because we are a military family, American Express waived the yearly cost. The 6% return on groceries is terrific. The returns practically wipe out any sales tax we might pay. This is the only card I use for grocery purchases. 3% back on gas is pretty good, and the Blue Cash Preferred is my go to when gas is not the currently recognized category on my Chase Freedom card. I initially thought I'd close this card after receiving the incentive pay, but the grocery and gas rewards have kept me using this card. My only complaint is that I've had to contact American Express a couple of times to get purchases re-categorized. Customer service has always addressed the issue immediately.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: This card definitely has some advantages over some prepaid cards. The $50 sign up bonus is definitely enticing, although my current card, U.S. Direct Express, does not charge any monthly fee. So I guess the $50 could be viewed as 50 months worth of fees being paid for up front. The American Express name is well known of course, but not taken at as many places as Mastercard or Visa, so that is something else to remember when thinking about whether this card is right for you.

The American Express Gold Card seems like a good card. The thing I like about the card is that you can receive reward points and use them for gift cards for dining, entertainment, and to shop at over 300 different merchants. I also like how I can get discounts and some low rates on hotels and resorts. It’s great not to have any annual fees for the first year. The only thing I dislike is that if you have a late fee from zero to the greater 35 or 2.99% of the delinquent balance would be charged to your accounts. Other than that it seems like a great card to have.

The benefits of the Platinum Card from American Express are pretty amazing -- 25,000 member points for signing up and using the card for $2,000 in purchases in three months, the free year of Amazon prime and the additional premium access. After using Capital One's Quicksilver card, I've become a huge fan of reward points that can be redeemed. They can even offset a minimal annual fee. But this $450 fee seems extremely excessive. Even other American Express cards don't have near that steep of a fee, which is what I think is the ultimate detriment to this card. If you can justify that fee each year, then it's certainly one to look into.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The Blue from American Express card seems like it has a very good rewards structure centered toward travel, similar to that of the Chase Sapphire card. The Chip Technology included in this card is very convenient when traveling abroad, and this is one of the only cards currently offering this chip in the US. The foreign transaction fee is slightly lower than others that I have seen. This card is especially attractive since there is no annual fee and it has an introductory APR offer (which is par for many credit cards recently). In conclusion, the APR, Penalty fees, and other terms seem average, if not slightly better than other cards that I have seen.

This card is a sleek silver looking card at first glance. The positives first are that the first year you do not have an annual fee, however after that it is 95 per year. For a card that requires such a high credit rating to qualify for there are other cards with smaller annual fees. But other than that that is the only negative. The roadside assistance is very helpful if you take long trips or breakdown on the side of the road when traveling over a 100 miles from home. Fraud protection is always a plus with all the identity theft going on and you can pay your card in full and pay no interest.

I like the American Express Prepaid card. It allows you to put a good amount of money on the card, while most prepaid cards only allow a couple hundred. I also like the fact that after you have been using this card for a while, you may qualify for a real credit card, while other cards do not. Good card.

"0% intro APR on purchases and balance transfers for 15 months" is worth it alone.

50 Reward Dollars and the amazon prime make it the best card out there.

sign up was easy also.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content:
This card is amazing. It has so many benefits.

Pros: 25000 Membership benefits.

I get to use Amazon Prime.

No Foreign Transaction Fees.

Cons: No predetermined credit limit.

$450 Annual Fees
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The American Express Gold Card seems to have some perks that would make it a good choice, as long as you pay your balance every month (as is true of most credit cards). Still, I like that American Express doesn't gouge you with outrageous APR, and though their late fees would add up if you failed to pay them off each month, if you stay on top of your bills, it doesn't seem like a bad deal. The $125 yearly fee may be difficult for some cardholders, but that beats a ridiculous APR any day, in my book, and I do like the perks and points system, which you can use for dining, entertainment, etc. And if you travel a lot, there are discounts at some hotels, so this card may be an even better fit. So a good card overall, especially for those that travel and that are good with paying their bill on time.

The American Express Serve card is a great option if you are looking for a prepaid card. You'll get $50 after two direct deposits of $250 or more, and that's one of the best prepaid offers I've seen. The only thing I can really think of that would be a problem is that not everyone accepts american express. Other than that, the American Express Serve is a pretty fair offer.

I found out about the American Express Blue Cash card through a close friend, and I am so glad that I did. My credit scores have risen, and now I have my own personal card to use at college. The grace period is long enough to manage my finances, and there are zero domestic transaction fees, which is great. I have had zero issues with places accepting American Express, which is also a relief. The ease of the card as well as the amazing online service made this a decision I do not regret. The online service is easy to navigate and my information and money feel secure and safe. Overall a fantastic card and online service.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The Blue from American Express Credit Card is a great card if you have a lot of big purchases to make. It requires you to have excellent credit, but for a good reason. The rates are moderately low, and the reward system is wonderful for big ticket spenders. If you travel a lot, I highly recommend this card. Over-all, it's a card on par with others of it's value, but has a little bit nicer perks than I've seen.

I am not that impressed with the features of the American Express Green Card. Its rewards only offer one point for every dollar spent which is below many of the current offers on the market. I have the Capital One Quick Silver card and I earn 1.5% back on every dollar spent and I don't have to pay an annual fee. The AMEX Green Card does not have a spending limit, but you are required to pay off your balance every month. The one upside is its fraud protection guarantee which does help protect the consumer against fraud. Aside from that, I would say there are much better options available on the market.

The initial bonus and Amazon Prime membership (worth another $79) is an okay benefit to this Blue Cash Preferred card from American Express. However, this American Express suffers from having a $75 annual fee. There are way too many credit cards, including Blue Sky cards from American Express (if you catch them at the right time), out there that do not have an annual fee to ever get one with a $75 annual fee. You would be better off to get one without the annual fee and use the money saved towards an Amazon prime subscription (if that is something you want).
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I find that this points card is a disingenuous way to encourage you to spend more money on your card. Despite this though the interest for these cards is very low. However I find it much more rewarding to use a cash back card such as the Blue Cash American Express Card. I save far more money using that credit card than I ever would with this Hilton Card.

One of the best travel rewards cards out there. Excellent sign up bonus and absolutely spectacular rewards programs when redeemed for flights or Starwood hotel properties. Any purchase at a Starwood property with these card nets you nearly 10% back with the SPG & Amex rewards combined, when redeemed for high value stays. You can also transfer 20,000 starpoints for 25,000 airline miles with many airlines. The small annual fee is nothing in comparison to what you'll earn by using this at starwood resorts.
department: Starwood Preferred Guest® Credit Card from American Express

content: If you travel frequently, I can see the reason why people might choose Blue Sky. The key incentive is the $100 credit per 7500 points earned. At $1 per point, you have to spend $7500 to get $100 in travel credit. And so it's like getting 1.33% back, compared to the standard 1% cash back found in a lot of cards. But if you don't travel much, there are better options. I use the Chase Freedom card because it has the standard 1% cash back and 5% cash back in rotating categories.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: I like that the introductory rate on this Blue Cash Everyday card is 0% APR for 15 months on purchases and balance transfers. Most other credit cards introductory rate is only for 12 months. I also like that there is no penalty or fee for going over your credit card limit.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The Blue from American Express is a rewards card much like the PenFed card. It has a points reward system which I personally do not like. The interest rate on this card is pretty hefty compared to PenFed's rather small 9.99%. This card does offer a 0% intro rate which could be useful if you need to make a big purchase immediately. Unlike most typical Amex cards, this one doesn’t have to be paid in full every month and there’s no annual fee.

The American Express Green card seems to have a decent rewards system in place that caters to frequent travelers. I tend to prefer the traditional cards from Bank of America, Capital One, Citibank, etc over Amex because the structure is completely different. Amex is full of fees in lieu of interest, but you cannot carry a balance.

There are cards like Chase Freedom that offer only some benefits. The prime feature that I really enjoy in this card is the 6% cash back feature on supermarkets. That is an amazing feature for anyone that often goes to buy groceries. Most cards will only offer 2% max cash back from very specific and useless stuff. It even comes with cash back when purchasing gas, which is a big purchase. I also am surprised that it comes with a amazon prime membership along with the 100 dollars it gives. That's like 200 dollars back. All in all, it seems like a really great card with many benefits.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: This card is great. Yes there is an annual fee, but you get amazon prime for a year, so it's sort of like just paying for amazon prime. The cash back is the best, you get lots back from groceries and gas, while getting 1% back on everything else.On top of all that, you get 100$ initially when joining. So that in itself already covers over a year of the annual fee. This card is great.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content:
Blue Cash Preferred from American Express - 6% for groceries and 3% for gas, both great deals, but there has to be a catch.

These percentages are high and not likely to stick around for long. It seems like they want to lure you in and then they will change the terms. I will not ever have a credit card that I have to pay a fee to have. The company is already making money off of my interest, and they want to charge me additional money? So, in reality, you really are paying for the Amazon Prime subscription. I like the 0% interest bonus but you better have excellent credit or your percentage is going to be sky high after 15 months. I think there are better credit card options out there. The only positive I see is that you can use your rewards to pay your card balance.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I received my American Express Serve card through the League of Legends RP+ rewards program. The card was free and I received it in about a week after registering. It's very easy and free to load money onto it by going to CVS or 7-Eleven. There are some fees associated with the card, but by using direct deposit you can avoid them. I earned about $100 worth of League of Legends RP by hitting all the milestones and then afterwards I receive RP for each dollar I spend. If you play league of legends or need a low cost/free American Express card then I'd highly recommend this.

I really like the rewards and benefits American Express gold offers. I dine out and shop a lot so getting points for that would be awesome. I had the capital one prestige card and I got 0 rewards, Also the fees aren't too bad. It would be nice to not have any for a full year.

There are a lot of good things about this card like if I spend $2,000 in the first 3 months I will get about 25,000 points, and plus I can use this card with Amazon.com because I do enjoy shopping on there, what I don't like about it is the annual fee I think it's a bit too much in my opinion. Comparing it to the Blue Cash Preferred from American Express the annual fee with $75 is really good for me! and I can earn 6% cash back and 3% when I go to the gas station.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The Blue Cash Everyday card from American Express has a nice overall feel to it, starting with no annual fee. It gets a little better with its bonus plan, giving back $50 after you spend $1,000 within the first three months. They also specialize in incentives, offering new signups Amazon Prime for a year after spending $1,000 in the first 3 months. The Blue Cash Everyday card also offers 3% cash back at US supermarkets on up to $6,000 per year. This is a great card for people who find themselves spending a lot of money on groceries.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: Blue Cash Preferred is probably my favorite AMEX card. The annual fee of only $75 is awesome, the reward system is top line, and the regular rate is not that high either. Plus, the initial bonus of $100 and the free 1 year of amazon prime are just awesome added bonuses. This is a card one should definitely check out.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I love the 3% cash back from supermarkets, 2% on gas and 1% everything else. It's much better than the bank of america visa that I have. I've had it for about a year now and I've earned a lot of cash back. I also love the offers that it has where there is cash back if you purchase from a certain store. Those have definitely come in handy!
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: hell no if i could rate neg 5 stars i would .. dont do it ... long story short i made up this account to add money from my husbands card number for bills mind you he left it to me because he went off to kuwait i used it on bluebird for a couple months then low and behold! my account is under review ?? i called customer service and they said i cant use it unless it had my name on it and they took it off my account really great... so now today 12/18/2013 i tried to add MY debit card with MY name on it and once again people my account is under review .. smh.. i called customer service again and they said i couldnt use that card because its a prepaid card (paypal) so um ok i decided to just close my account but its neg 4 cents really 4 damn cents lol so they couldnt close it smh ripping my card up as i type ugh .. they are dong too much ... no one has time for that ! would not recommend .. dont bank with them evaaa !!

The American Express Prepaid card is pretty good as far as prepaid cards are concerned. There are no types of activation or monthly fees, so it has that advantage over other prepaid cards. I like that they let you get up to three cards with your account. This allows family members the option to each have access to the card. This could be very handy if you wanted to use this card just for groceries or other expenses that you and your family want to keep on a budget. I also like that you can add money to the account using direct deposit - very convenient. The downside of this prepaid card is that they charge you $2 per ATM withdrawal (after your first each month). Outside of that, there is little reason not to consider the American Express prepaid card if you're in the market for a prepaid card.

I use my Serve card frequently and have had no real issues with it. I signed up for the card during the $50 promotion (you got 50 bucks if you deposited 500) and have been happy with it ever since. I mainly use it as a savings card, I'll deposit 5% of my paycheck in it and use it to save up for big purchases. There are NO fees with this card (except the small ATM fees) which makes it ideal for people who need/want to go the prepaid route. Most prepaid cards have a monthly fee or try to nickle and dime you every chance they get, but American Express has laid out a very user-beneficial fee program, i.e there are almost none.


This card is great, just keep in mind that not all retailers/stores accept American Express, that's the only drawback I can think of, everything else is perfect in relation to other prepaid cards on the market.

I have always been a fan of American Express because I think they offer some of

the best rewards out there. This card is no different. I love that they don't

set any limitations on how you earn points, so you get a reward for buying whatever

you want. And if you are a big traveler, you get double points! Another huge plus is the

intro rate of 0% for 15 months. Not many cards out there offer 0% interest. The normal apr is a little high, but these days, what card isn't?

I love how many rewards and benefits the American Express Green Card offers. So many

credit card companies these days offer benefits that really don't

do much for the customer. What we really want is money back and travel perks.

There is a small annual fee after the first year, but I don't really mind that

as long as I am getting something in return. This card is perfect for

people who don't necessarily use credit to carry a balance, but want to

make their money work for them.

The great thing about this card is that it's from American Express and they've always offered great customer service. It's also a good tool if you're trying to cut back on using credit. I load my card with my monthly food budget and it helps me stay on track with spending. I just use my debit card to reload it when it runs out. I'd never used a prepaid card regularly before I tried this one, but I had been given a Visa prepaid card as a birthday gift one year and liked the convenience while knowing I wasn't going to rack up interest. However, I chose to go with the American Express prepaid card because it's easier to add money to.

American Express is ideal if you hate carrying a balance and like to put all your bills on one card. I do this so I earn points, which can then be used to pay off some of those bills. When it comes to travel, American Express is the best because you know you're protected if something goes wrong. As long as you don't overspend, this card is a great choice for purchases and travel. I find having to pay the whole balance helps me control my spending and budget better.

The Blue from American Express Credit Card is an ideal card for those that travel, accepted in so many countries, with decent rewards that can cover many of your travel costs with no annual fee. A solid intro rate and reasonable interest rate after the initial 15 months, Blue is a must have in the wallet of a busy traveler.

From what I have experienced so far, the Bluebird Card by American Express is a very viable prepaid option. For ordinary transactions, there are no fees. There are no maintenance fees either. You can also use checks with this card, though they are pricey to obtain. Getting cash can be an issue because they do charge for that. Direct deposit is a snap with this card. The mobile allows you to remotely deposit checks, which is a real convenience. Overall, I’m pleased with the card.

The American Express Green Card seems ok. The idea behind it is amazing. Although the high annual fee would drive me away from it. The travel benefits and rewards it offers are surpassed by other cards that don't charge as high an annual fee as this one. For me this card is average at best.

Blue Cash Everyday Card from American Express is my very favorite credit card. I love earning 5% back on gas, groceries, and drugstores once I have met the required threshold of spending for the year. I use my credit card for everything I can so I earn a nice chunk of change each year. I love being able to use the card at Costco, and American Express's customer service is unrivaled.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The Blue Cash Card from American Express is a great card that I've had for a year or so now. I get cash back on all my normal daily spending which is great. Is similar to Bank of America with the reward for everyday spending. 0% APR for 15 months is pretty great too. I would recommend this card to friends and family.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The American Express Green Card is a great card in my opinion. It's not so much a credit card as it is cash with extra rewards and security. You don't get to carry a balance on the card which sounds inconveniencing but you never pay interest either. There is a small yearly fee of 95 dollars after the first year which is basically 7.90 a month. This best part about the card is the security. Any fraudulent purchase or stolen cards and you don't pay a penny. That's a lot safer than cash and you don't have to worry about online shopping or credit card phishing scams. The other added benefit is the rewards points which is the exact same as the American Express Gold Card so you know your getting great offers. Altogether I think this is an interesting idea and a great card.

I used to have one of the Blue from American Express cards for years before switching to their One card. I didn't travel, but I could see the big traveler was who this card was designed for. The customer service was great, but you need a very high credit score to get one. This would be a good choice if your employer uses these for company cards for expense accounts, because if you use it a lot the points really rack up. I used to give family members plane tickets with it because I was stuck working on the Internet most of the time years ago. Be sure to put 1k through it the first 90 days for the bonus, also if they give you a good limit you can balance transfer anything you can pay off in 15 months with no interest (but there is a fee).

The American Express Gold Card is an excellent choice if you can pay the full balance every month. Utilizing the Gold Hotel Collection perk could more than pay for the annual fee that starts during the second year. The American Express Gold Card is better than most cards I've had like it. The points and discounts you earn really make this card worth having, and no other card can really compete with it.

The Platinum Card from American Express is a card for those that have excellent credit. The outrageous annual fee of $450 when looked at after examining the benefits this card offers isnt all that outrageous anymore. You get unlimited free 2 day shipping from amazon. That in itself if you shop a lot on amazon would pay for itself. You also get 25,000 reward points if you spend $2,000 within the first 3 months. One negative about this card is that the balance must be paid in full each month. This is a VIP card truly with the perks it offers, and in my opinion blows a lot of other rewards cards out of the water. I highly recommend this card if you qualify.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The American Express Serve card is a decent prepaid card but there are others that are better. I mainly took advantage of the extra $50 dollars you get for depositing $500 dollars. There are not many merchants that accept American Express in my area so I rarely use this card besides getting money out of the ATM. The great thing about this card over many other prepaid card is that there is not Fees to use this card. Other than that, the benefits of other cards are better.

If you are a frequent traveler who likes to stay in Hilton Hotels, the Hilton Credit Card just might be the card for you! The initial bonus of 40,000 points is a huge perk and you'll be racking up more points in no time. The interest rate is actually pretty decent for this kind of card, 15.24% - 19.24%, with rates similar to some cashback cards, such as the American Express Blue Cash Card. The no annual fee makes this a no brainer for Hilton lovers.

The Blue from American Express Credit Card is a great card in the way of security alone with the Smart chip technology you don't have to worry as much about making purchases outside the U.S. where i've found is usually how people steal credit card information because they are in a different country and feel safer stealing the information there or something. Then you got the overdraft protection so if something does happen they can't over charge your card either. There is no annual fee which is something i always look at because with a great card like this with no fee why get one with a fee? The points add up fast and you can book a flight with them in just a few clicks. This is a great card

The American Express Green Card is an interesting idea, although I am not sure how well it truly works in practice. For starters, it isn't much of a credit card given that the entire balance must be paid in full each month. Granted, that does allow a card holder time to acquire the necessary funds, but not nearly as much as other credit cards would. On the other hand, the rewards offered by this card are truly excellent. Pay with points allows you to pay for virtually everything without spending any money on it, using your accumulated points to finance your entire vacation. The real negative with this card is not the payment in full aspect, however. It is the annual fee. While it is waived for the first year, it shoots up to a steep $95 per year after that. Seems a little expensive for me given that the card does not really function the way others with much fees rates would.

The blue from American Express is the perfect card for the person who loves to travel. This American Express card allows you to earn points that don't have a cap on the number that you can have and they also don't expire. You can then use those points at twenty different airlines which gives you a lot of flexibility when it comes to flight dates and times to get that perfect flight. What makes this card even better is that the 0%APR introductory period is for 15 months, 3 months longer than most cards. Take for instance the RC Willey card. It gives you 0%APR for 12 months. Overall the Blue from American Express is a great card to check out if you have excellent credit.

One of the more prestigious cards on the market, the American Express Gold Card is the card to be seen with. With its endless discounts on restaurant and hotel purchases, the Gold is one no traveler wants to be without. It is, however, important that consumers know just exactly what they are getting into when signing up for the card. A balance due in full at the end of every month isn't for everybody, and you may want to determine in advance whether you are going to rack up enough rewards from use to offset the $125 annual fee. Overall, a very solid card for its purpose!

Ok, let’s talk about the elephant in the room, and I’m talking about the $450 dollar annual fee. Is it worth it? Do you purchase a lot of stuff from amazon, because if you do, the unlimited free two-day shipping could save you lots of money if you do, easily overcoming that annual fee. But then again, that’s only for the first year. After that, you have to pay to keep Amazon Prime. How about the 25,000 reward point you get when you spend $2,000 in the first three months. That’s a nice bonus, but it’s also a one-time deal. After you get that bonus, there are no more like it. So what it boils down to is that there are no real perks after the first year of ownership to offset that $450 annual fee. My advice, keep looking.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: I have had Gold Delta SkyMiles credit card from American Express for 4 months. The card is available to those who have a good credit. The main deciding factor to enroll was the additional credit it adds and the double miles it generates. After I purchased two Delta tickets that exceeded 500 dollars, I got an immediate 50 dollar credit. Also, the card speeds up the Delta mileage accumulation by giving double the miles with every ticket purchase. It also gives a free first bag check. Additionally, the card provides a numerous number of cash-back offers with several stores and websites. I am totally satisfied with my Delta SkyMiles credit card.
department: Delta SkyMiles® Gold American Express Card

content: I love my Serve card. I love the fact that I can email money to anyone I want, this is extremely convenient for me. I also love the free atm withdrawals with my direct deposits. There is also no fees which is rare for a pre-paid card now a days. And the deal of depositing 250$ and you get 50$ free!! Who wouldn't want free money.

This was a good card for my two small businesses. The point system was kind of fun to spend each year on holiday gifts from their catalog. Amex seems to have the best customer service of any issuer, as long as you pay the balance each month they were always nice to us. There's no annual fee which I'd never pay just for the privilege of doing business with a place, it seems ridiculous. You'll really have to do the math on it versus a cash back card like the One card, but they have so much to pick from it's pretty cool to do holiday shopping at the end of the year if you use it a lot.
department: The Blue Business® Plus Credit Card from American Express

content: Everything about this card was given as promised. This goes for the $100 reward for spending $1,000 in the first 3 months (at the time it was $100, but no free Amazon Prime membership), and the 3%, 2%, and 1% cash back rewards respectively. However, each reward took very long to appear in my account, 8 weeks at the very most. I shouldn't complain since it's free money, and with a relatively low redemption minimum of $25 in reward dollars. But, I was a bit taken back since other credit card companies give their cash back rewards in as little as 48 hours. Still, great card, great American Express #1 quality customer service, and really a 4.5 of 5 star card if I could make it that.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The American Express prepaid card is a pretty good card. I think with a prepaid card, you are spending money you HAVE, and keeping track of your purchases. American express prepaid has high deposit limits, and minimal fees. Although, I would prefer if they had partnered with some bank that offers free ATM transactions, rather than just one free transaction yearly, and then a $2 fee from then on. I would personally appreciate that option to use an ATM for free most of the time. One major downfall is limited locations accept American Express. Overall, the American Express prepaid card is flexible, and a good deal. It would just be better with free ATM’s and if more stores accepted it!

I have had this card since 2003. When it came out it was the design of the card that grabbed my attention and ever since that, it has been in my wallet. I have 10 other credit cards but American Express service is the best in my opinion. I had this card stolen twice in the past and on both occasions, AmEx properly took care of the issue, reversing the charges. I would highly recommend this card to anyone, though you need to have a good credit score for AmEx approval.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: This was my favorite card until the recession hit and they started scaling back the credit limit (unlike the Chase card that kept it the same). If you qualify for it, then absolutely put $1,000 through it the first 90 days to get the $100 bonus. Also the Amazon Prime shipping is a good deal if you buy through them a lot like I do. I just don't know how they do some of the cash back rewards like 6 percent at grocery stores when that place swipe rate is going to be around 2 percent or less to begin with.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The American Express Gold Card is great option for a lot of people. The rewards with this card are near the top of the game, there's no annual fee for the first year but you can expect to pay One hundred and twenty five per year after that, which is pretty high in my opinion. If you are approved for this card then you for sure have pretty good credit so don't expect it if you don't. This card carries a level of prestige similar to the "Visa Black Card".

I've been using The Platinum Card from American Express for over a year and couldn't be any happier. The annual fee is a very pricey $450 but they start you off with some benefits. A free year of Amazon Prime and Premium Access are great. Amazon Prime alone can save hundreds of dollars if you're a big online shopper. With all that shopping you'll also bump up your reward points. If you can look past the annual fee, The Platinum Card from American Express is great to have.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: I have always enjoyed the convenience of prepaid cards, however, in the past I have run into problems with deposit amounts and number of additional cards allowed. The American Express Prepaid Card allows up to $5,000 in direct deposit and $2,500 in cash deposits per month which is considerably more flexible than other cards I have looked into in the past. With AMEX prepaid, you have the option of having up to 3 cards. This is particularly useful, especially when teaching children how to budget or monitoring their spending habits. The one thing I am disappointed in with this card is ATM fees. You are only allowed one withdrawal per month, after that you will be charged $2.00 each time you go to the ATM. Other than that, I feel that the American Express Prepaid Card is a great option for anyone looking for the convenience of a prepaid card.

Although at first glance the American Express Green Card looks like a great one to add to your arsenal of credit cards, I am not too thrilled about the annual fee. Right now, 95$ a year for each year after the first one is a little too steep for my wallet. There are far too many other cards that offer almost the exact same perks as this one, (minus the prestigious name of course). I would use it for all it is worth the first year, and then consider whether or not I would want to pay $100 each year afterwards. I do like the fact that I get points for travel for every purchase I make. I think that in itself is the card's saving grace for me.

The blue from American Express is pretty exceptional card for anyone interested in a credit card that offers nice rewards for its members. Their offer of 10,000 points for spending $1000 within the first 3 months is sweet. As well as having a pretty low interest rate for most. Someone would have to have pretty good credit to qualify for this card.

Blue Cash Preferred from American Express is a great rewards card especially if you frequently make purchases on Amazon. This card provides a year of free Amazon Prime membership which gives you free 2 day shipping on most items and Amazon movies. My APR is quite high for this card due to my credit score, but I pay of the balance monthly therefore avoiding interest fees.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The Hilton Credit Card seems like it would be a great fit if you traveled often. The rewards system is a nice feature, especially the initial bonus. The transfer rate and annual percentage rate are almost identical to the credit cards I now have. An especially nice feature of the rewards system is that there are no blackout dates when redeeming your points. My Amtrak reward card is notorious for only allowing certain dates for redemption. The one thing I don't like is the foreign transaction fee. If you're someone who travels a lot, this would be a bit of a nuisance. If you take into consideration that there is no annual fee however, it kind of balances out the foreign transaction fee. The Hilton Credit Card looks like a good option overall especially if you travel often.

For a pre-paid card this one seems to be worthwhile. From the get go seeing that I get free withdrawals at ATMs if I have direct deposit is a huge plus. It’s like having the benefits of using a commercial bank. I also like the fact that this card has direct deposit in general. No worrying about having to get a paycheck and head somewhere to cash it – my money would be automatically loaded on pay days. There are no other fees associated with this card so it seems like a win-win situation. No credit check and they want to give you $50 for making two $250+ deposits? Count me in.

Free amazon prime for a year? Sweet I'll bite. American Express offers some of the best membership rewards on all of their cards, including extended warranties, and extended return periods. Unfortunately this card does have a rather steep annual fee which I typically avoid when considering different offers, but the benefits this card offers outweigh the disappointment of an annual fee (for the first year) By spending 1000 in the first 3 months The Blue Cash Preferred card will offer you a 100 statement credit. The 6 percent grocery savings this card offers will be a valuable savings to the members of my family, and 3 percent on gas is nice also. The most tempting part of the offers are 0 apr for 15 months 6 percent savings on gas, but free amazon prime? You can't beat that! it's a 79 value, and Amazon is my favorite retailer!
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: Most Americans would be owing an AmEx card, for some purpose or the other. That's the reach AmEx has. The American Express Green Card comes power packed with rewards, Roadside Assistance, Financial Control and Fraud Protection Guarantee which are really integral. But the annual fees would simply dissuade any genuine buyer and turn him away. I havent seen any card that charges $95 annual fee, I guess only the AmEx does that! But I guess the unlimited spending and reward points are simply too irresistible.

The blue from American Express credit card provides you with 10,000 points after you spend $1,000 in your first three months. That is pretty unheard of and a great perk to getting this credit card. Another thing I like is the fact you get 0% APR for 15 months. Other than the initial points you get it seems like it would be very hard to rack up some more points with it being 1 point for every $1 spent. The interest rate after 15 months is not too bad based on other reward cards its well below the average. It is still relatively high APR but that's to be expected from a reward card. Overall I would say this is a pretty good rewards card.

The Blue Cash has astounding features to support it. Its a real steal to get a year's Amazon Prime account for free. I always shop online, be it BestBuy or Amazon and I have always felt bad to pay for shipping items less than $25. This card would be a great deal for that matter. However, I hate the reward points. I always vote for the cash back as I would be able to use the money to my taste rather than getting bound to shop in select stores under certain conditions! Had the initial $100 reward been in terms of real money, I would give it a 5 on 5. However, the Amazon Prime membership is something I havent seen with the other cards and the Blue Cash stands out for that!
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I would give this credit card an additional star had they not decided to cancel the best benefit which was the companion ticket. I plan to upgrade at the end of this year (for $150) to regain it. Otherwise, the free checked baggage and SkyMiles accrual are still nice to receive. I'm also pleased with my line of spending and have never had a problem making payments and checking other information online. I have heard some people have had less than ideal experiences with their customer service, but so far I have had little reason to get in touch. Overall, I have saved a quite a bit on airfare over the years I've been a cardholder and can't imagine going back.
department: Delta SkyMiles® Gold American Express Card

content: I don't typically go for cards that rely on a point system. My current card, the Discover It Student, allows me to earn actual cash back and spend my earnings online. However, I do like that this card have a low interest rate (much lower than any of the three I currently hold) and I appreciate that. The Hilton Credit Card doesn't require much credit in order for you to qualify. The 25 day grace period is amazing for someone like me who just got out of college and trying to establish himself, we can't always make payments on the due date; but we do what we can and Hilton understands that.

I love the Blue Sky card offer from American Express. This card offers NO annual fee, along with an introductory point bonus equal to 100 towards a car rental, airline ticket or hotel stay! The only requirement to achieve the bonus is spending 1000 in the first 3 months. The card has a respectable apr, that doesn't kick in for the first 15 months of use. Obviously we all love credit card offers that offer a great introductory period, and zero percent for 15 months is great. This card also comes with all the benefits of having an American Express card, the cards offer great security, they are accepted almost everywhere, and come with an added bonus of offering an extended warranty on most items purchased with the card. As long as the item purchased carries a man. warranty of less than 5 years, American Express will extend the warranty for an additional year. Did you know that American Express users are also offered extended returns? If you attempt to take a purchase back to the store within the first 90 days and the store won't accept it, American Express will cover the purchase price up to $300, and up to $1000 annually. What does your card do for you? This is a great choice for anyone looking for a new card.

In addition to all the benefits previously mentioned, you may have a card that the intro apr has expired on. Transfer that balance to the new Blue Sky American Express, and you won't pay any interest on the balance the only cost is a 3% fee for taking on the additional risk.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: I believe the features of this AMEX Prepaid card are top notch compared to its competitors. The fact that it has no activation fee nor monthly fee make it convenient to use month-to month. Couple that with the fact that there is no cancellation fee or inactivity fee, this is basically a risk free card to get. I once had a Chase Liquid Prepaid card, and it would charge me a monthly fee to use the card. I would highly suggest getting an AMEX Prepaid card for anyone interested in getting a card that won’t charge them money to spend their money!

The Platinum Card from American Express has a huge annual fee of $450, but it also comes with a lot of benefits. There is no interest rate because the balance has to be paid in full every month. You get Amazon Prime for free which normally costs $79. The reward points offer a lot of benefits if you’re a big spender as well and it comes with bonus points with some qualification steps needed. There aren’t many other cards like this card to compare it to, but it would be perfect if you never carry a balance and want a lot of rewards. Otherwise you should just get a traditional card.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The American Express Gold Card is a good option, especially for those who travel a lot. The discounts and low rates at hotels would be quite convenient for a savvy traveler. American Express has excellent customer service, which is a huge perk in the credit card industry. The annual fee of $125 is a big negative. If you are going to offset that amount substantially by the amount you earn in rewards, then by all means, choose this card. But there are other American Express cards that have no annual fee. The American Express Blue Cash card has rewards, no annual fee, and of course no interest charges when you pay off your balance in full each month.

This card is the worst mistake that I have ever made… I will make sure that everyone including my parents and brother-in-law and sister-in-laws that I recommended this card to DO NOT OBTAIN THIS CARD AND DO NOT ACTIVATE… There are so many restrictions on this card that you can’t even use this card and feel comfortable. Let me say that “THIS IS MY MONEY!!!!” I direct deposit and put my hard earned cash on this card and I am limited at every step as to how, where, and how much of MY OWN MONEY that I am allowed to get. I linked a bank account to this card and then after you shut my card down multiple times so that you can “verify” my bank account, I find out that I can only transfer $100.00 per day. For the number of times that I had to call and send information and you shutting my card down made the $100.00 per day not worth the trouble. Then, I direct deposit my check on the card and American Express has all of my money tied up on this card. After my first check was deposited I used the ATM for cash and of course it shut me down at $2500.00 per month!!! Funny how this is never mentioned until you need the money. But, I can deal with that as long as my card works.

AMERICAN EXPRESS LEFT ME STRANDED 4 HOURS FROM HOME WITH MY HANDICAPPDED WIFE AND 3 MONTH OLD INFANT IN FREAZING WEATHER BECAUSE I HAD SPENT THE MONTHLY LIMIT ALLOWED ON MY CARD!!!!!!! THIS IS MY MONEY!!!! HELLO!!!! This is not a credit card... I put my money on this card I should be able to use my money to get my family home no matter what the circumstances...

So, evidently, after I drove 4 hours from home to buy the food supplements that my wife needs LETS DON’T FORGET THAT MY WIFE IS HANDICAPPED AND HAS TO HAVE SPECIAL CARE. I find out that there is a $10,000 per month limit that you can spend of YOUR MONEY. After my card didn’t work at the store for my wife’s food supplements, I called AMEX and of course the reason my card didn’t work was because they had to verify my bank account ONE MORE TIME (this is the third time). While I had the representative on the phone I once again emailed my bank account info and she once again verified my account and said that my card will be good in 5 minutes. I went back in the store and of course my card didn’t work. I called back and after being on hold for another 10 minutes the representative answered and started going through the list of reasons that it might not work. Then she said, “Mr. McBride, the reason your card isn’t working is because you are at your monthly limit of $10,000 and your card will not work until December 1.” I explained to her that my ENTIRE pay check was direct deposited on that card and that AMEX had already limited me on ATM availability so that I had NO ACCESS TO MY CASH. I told her that we are going to have to figure something out because this is going to strand me and my family 4 or 5 hours from home and that they need to at least let the charge at the store I was at and for me to get gas to get my family home. She said, “Sorry, but there is nothing that we can do.” I asked for a supervisor and was on hold for 1 hour and 34 minutes and she never got back on the line one time to check on me or to let me know that she was trying to contact someone. 30 minutes into this call I called on my other phone to see why no one answered on the other line. This lady was nice and helpful and she came back and at least let me know that she was working on getting someone. After being on hold with her for 45 minutes she finally got someone on the line and they told me the same thing. That AMEX WAS NOT GOING TO DO ANYTHING FOR ME AND HAD NO REGUARD TO LEAVING MY FAMILY STRANDED AWAY FROM HOME. DID I MENTION THAT MY WIFE IS HANDICAPPED AND SHE CANT WALK AND THAT WE ALSO HAVE A 3 MONTH OLD INFANT IN FREEZING WEATHER??? AND DID I MENTION THAT THIS IS MY MONEY THAT I DIRECT DEPOSITED FROM MY PAYCHECK???

I HAVE TO SAY THAT AS I MENTIONED ON THE RECORDED LINE THAT THIS IS MORE THAN “OH, SORRY YOU HIT THE LIMIT ON THE AMOUNT OF YOUR MONEY THAT YOU CAN HAVE ACCESS TO” THIS IS NOW AN ETHICAL ISSUE….. You can bet that I will do everything in my power to publicize this information and make sure that everyone knows the fine print that will leave your family stranded with NO HELP!!!

We love using this card for all of our business needs. When we signed up we received over $500 in bonus points that were quickly used on some much needed expenses. We love the no preset spending limit as well. This has helped us purchase things that we haven't been able to easily in the past. A lot of our business is done via credit card and being a newer business our limit was always reached easily on our other card that we have. The things you can redeem your points for are also awesome. There are so many different types of items you can get. We also love the bonuses that they offer every season with different types of merchants. I would recommend this card to any business looking for a great solution.

I find it interesting that the Blue from American Express card has a grace period before you start getting charged with interest fees. I've never heard of this as none of the credit cards I have offer a grace period. I think this is a good thing so that you start off not having to worry about interest charges immediately. I like that they offer points although I'd generally go for cards that offer money back depending on how much you spend rather than a card that offers points.

The American express green card seems like a good card to add to your credit cards. Some good quality's about this card is there are 24/7 emergency assistance when traveling and that is always good to have just in case something happens. Also there is no interest charges because you pay your balance in full every month. Also the Green card has no preset spending limit it just adjusts with you, however you use the card. I mean the good quality's just keep going and going about this card. The only set backs I see of this card would be is the annual $95 fee after the first year or the 35 dollar late fee. Other than that is card seems to be one of the best offered on the market. I know I was looking at a Capital One credit card the other day and it did not offer anything as good as this American Express Green card does.

The American Express Prepaid Card is a useful option for the few people who may not have a bank account to use or for those wishing to give a gift, but not wanting to hand out cash. The American Express Prepaid Card comes with the excellent customer service provided by American Express for all its customers at a smaller cost.


The card itself has few fees. There are no annual or monthly fees, which are common with bank accounts and credit cards. Secondly, transactions cost nothing, with the exception of ATM withdrawals. There is one free ATM withdrawal a month, which is the obvious downfall to this card. After the initial withdrawal, $2 is charged per withdrawal, don't forget the ATM you use most likely has its own fee to add on top of that.


The benefit however, once you have the card is there is no cancellation fee, nor an inactivity fee, which is convenient since you can keep it around for later uses.


Compared to other prepaid cards I have used, this financial tool is less expensive and less fee based than most, making it a good selection for a prepaid card.

I think most people commenting do not fully understand the way an American Express card works. You pay a modest annual fee. It works out at about $10 a month. The first year is free. After that, you make purchases throughout the month, and pay it off in full at the end of the month. When you do that, you are not charged any interest at all on those purchases. If you use your card, as designed, you will not pay interest on your purchases – that’s why the $125 annual fee is so understandable. American Express makes most of its money from the merchant fees they collect. That is why this card is so desirable and exclusive. It’s not meant to be a long term financing option. Short term unlimited borrowing is what this card is intended for.

The Platinum card from American Express is the epitome of a practical and elegant credit card. The only reason I could see why an individual may not like it is because of the 495 dollar annual fee. The fee is easily compensated with the perks regarding this card. For example, you get 25,000 rewards points for spending 2,000$ in the first 3 months. The amazon prime is also a plus, and I have also used many of the perks regarding Ticketmaster presale concerts as well. The platinum card is also practical when travelling, because of the non-existent fee. Their customer service is world class, and I have never had an issue, and by itself is almost worth the fee. I would recommend this card to anyone that wants something better from their credit card company.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: Even with bad credit, you can still qualify for a Walmart credit card (I know because my mom’s credit is horrible and Walmart is the only one that gave her a credit card) so I can’t possibly understand why you would choose the prepaid option over it. But that said, as far as prepaid cards go this one is not horrible, it gives you pretty standard perks like ATM withdrawal and free pin use on the card and its monthly fees aren’t too bad at only three dollars. If you really would like a prepaid card then look at the American Express Serve card that has no monthly fee and gives you a chance to have direct deposits for free ATM use, it seems like a much better option.

It is simple. The best part about this card is the sign-up bonus credit of fifty bucks. Not too shabby, considering you have to deposit $500 via direct deposit first. It has the mobile app and other features that are offered by other brands and prepaid cards as well. Everything about this card is free, but it does not say if it supports credit purchases or just debit. One problem I would have is that there is barely any money-pass ATM's around my area. If more ATM's were in my area, I would definitely go with this. This prepaid card is going to, hopefully, do exactly what it is named after: serve.

The Hilton Credit Card is great! It doesn't require excellent credit to qualify and there isn't an annual fee. Cards similar to this usually have a rather hefty annual fee. They don't offer an intro rate, but their interest rate is just phenomenal! Starting at 15% to 19% interest rate, its considerably lower then their competitors. I can't say enough good things about this card. Their reward point system is really top notch. They offer a great initial bonus along with several perks and services. To top it off, there isn't a limit on how many points you can earn. This card is a must for frequent travelers. They also offer travel benefits like baggage insurance, rental car insurance and travel accident insurance. They have everything you would need for traveling.

The Blue Sky from American Express Card is great for someone with excellent credit. There's no annual fee and a 0% intro interest rate for the first 15 months. After your first 15 months, the interest rate isn't bad, a bit below average, at 17% to 22%. Their cash advance rate is rather high, so I would stay away from those transactions with this card. I do really like their rewards points. You get a fair amount of initial bonus points and there is no limit on how many points you can earn. For every 7,500 points that you earn, they can be redeemed for a $100 statement credit toward any airline ticket, any hotel stay, car rental or cruise. I think this card would definitely be useful to frequent travelers, looking to save a little bit of money.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The Blue Cash Preferred card is a decent card depending on how you use it. As long as you take advantage of the reward system, then it is decent, but the annual fee can be a hefty burden if you don't take full advantage of the rewards. It has comparable rewards to other cards, although during some promotional offers, I think I would rather take some of the other cards available since they don't have the annual fee attached. American Express does have great customer care however, and should be taken into consideration. They've always addressed my issues with amazing care, which some other companies do not do as well.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: This is an excellent option for those looking for a prepaid debit card. American Express has excellent customer service, and this most definitely extends to the American Express Prepaid Card. There are no activation or monthly fees - keep your money in your pocket. Many other prepaid cards, such as the Magic Prepaid Mastercard, come with a monthly fee. There are multiple options when it comes to making deposits to your card, which is highly convenient. The biggest downside is the limit of making one free ATM withdrawal per calendar month, and any additional withdrawals will be accompanied by a $2 fee. Shop with the confidence that if your card is lost or stolen, you won't be accountable for the fraudulent charges, just like with American Express credit cards such as the American Express Blue Cash Card.

This Blue Cash Preferred card seems to have a lot of the same benefits as other cash back cards. I already have one with my bank that has similar gas and base % back, but the grocery % is significantly higher. Unfortunately the bank offers my card for free and this one costs $75 a year and I'm not sure, even with the additional % that I can even make up for that fee. Another downside is that the card is American Express, which isn't accepted at as many vendors as Visa or Mastercard, which would make it even harder to accumulate enough cash back to make up for the fees.


I always pay the bill on time so the interest isn't of big concern to me.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: With American Express Serve , I have access to a whole new way to pay. It’s not a credit card – it’s a digital prepaid account. I can pay online or through an app on my smart phone or I can use the card I received that I can use anywhere American Express is accepted, if I simply want to pay in the traditional way. There’s no fee to sign up or a credit check. I am eligible for American Express benefits like purchase protection, roadside assistance, and special entertainment offers .It is wonderful and anyone can sign up for a Serve account. Since it isn’t a credit card, there’s no credit check – so regardless of credit history, anyone can enjoy all the advantages of Serve. I like the convenience and security of American Express, and this prepaid account is so easy to use, it makes a great alternative to a fee-laden checking account. I can pay online, easily split a bill with friends, or download the app and use my phone to make purchases. This is really a great card to have.

I love this card because there is no annual fee, as well as 0% APR, how can you go wrong with 0% APR? You cant, plain and simple, which is why I am recommending this card to everyone I know and love. I know as well as everyone else, these big banks are in it for themselves, so why not get a great card such as this one? With 0% APR you do not have to worry about interest piling up without your knowledge and owing more than you actually do. With 0% APR you can't go wrong which is why I love it!
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The American Express Gold Card is one of the best credit cards out there right now, in my opinion. The only reason I took a star away from this card, is because of the insanely high annual fee after the first year of $125. But I guess with all things that cost a bit of money, you do get quite a bit of perks. The first major one is, if you qualify, they give you a personalized interest rate. Lucky for me, I was able to get one locked in at about 10%. This is significantly lower than most of my other credit cards I have or had. Also, there is not a set credit line, they approve your purchases based on your payment history and your financial situation that is made aware to them. Pretty cool if you ask me!

I'm not a fan of fees - especially annual fees. The $95 fee seems like way too much to me. The benefits associated with this type of card is pretty typical with most cards. The travel benefits and points I find with plenty of cards which do not have an annual fee. I also see that this one forces the customer to pay off the balance each month, which is the traditional American Express model. Some other American Express cards have it to where this isn't part of the policy and actually allow one to pay the balance down over time which seems to be a better deal to me. Personally, this card doesn't cut it - others have the same if not better benefits!

This has a great sign up reward – 10,000 points for spending just $1000 in the first three months – easy. Most cards give you a bonus after you spend $3000 in the first 3 months. If you travel, this is a great card considering the double points for booking travel…but you have to do it through the American Express travel website. I have never booked through them so I don’t know if the rates are comparable to other travel sites. I would hate to spend more for a ticket just to get extra points. Overall the rewards seem restrictive. I wish they would state if you could get anything other than just travel. I’m a big fan of statement credit myself.

How can you go wrong with 0% APR and no annual fee? The Blue Sky American Express card is very good card, hence you have to have an excellent credit rating to obtain one. With a bonus of 7,500 points (after $1000 spending in your first 3 months), you practically have a $100 dollar voucher for travelling for using your card. With a 1:1 ration you can use this card towards any $100 voucher, whether its air, hotel, cruise, or hotels. The foreign transaction rate is slightly higher than most cards at 2.7%, and a 17-22% interest rate which is also on the higher side. But if you are looking for a card that is easy to maintain and get's you some perks, this card has a lot to it. If you are looking for more mileage or options for rewards, there are other cards from airlines themselves that give double miles.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: This card seems very basic with little options. It is a good prepaid card for those who just want a credit card with no perks or benefits. There are no hidden fees, which is very favorable, for cancellation or signup. The $2 out of network fee though seems high. If you deposit twice $250 they add $50 to your account which is decent. Free money. This doesnt seem as attractive as vanilla, but having the option to add money, and then withdraw money is a highly desirable card in my opinion. It is a hybrid of a credit card and an atm card. What also is cool is that you can email money to someone, none of my cards can currently do that. If only able to add points through spending, this card would be awesome! The only question is how easy is it to add funds to your card, and where can you do it?

The Blue Cash Preferred card from American Express looks like it has pros and cons. While it has great cash back perks on grocery shopping and gas, and there is a great initial bonus of $150, there is also an annual fee of $75 dollars. If you start out with a low credit limit, this will eat away at your balance right away. In my opinion, this would not be a good "starter" credit card for a young adult or college student due to the annual fee. When I was starting in college, I opened a similar card with Capital One with a $300 limit and a $100 annual fee. It was maxed out within a few months and I was stuck paying it off as a student. Food for thought!
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I much prefer this card to the Hyatt card because there is no annual fee, and the rewards system gives you a comparable points system based on the amount you spend. You start off with a hefty chunk of reward points already too, which can immediately be used for free nights and other related services with the Hilton hotel chain. A great card for frequent travelers or people that want to save up free stays for a vacation, this card is a solid performer. The only potential downside is that this is an American Express card, which is not as widely accepted as the Visa and Mastercard alternatives.

I have used the American Express Prepaid Card for quite sometime now, and i must that i really enjoy using this. I like it most because its a no hassle type of card that you can use anywhere that uses debit. It makes it even better that it carries the branding as well. I truly live by the slogan of "don't leave home without it". I would recommend this card to anyone who is tired of using other name brands that gives them too many issues. I feel this card will ease them in such a big way! I give this 10/10!!

This platinum card would be perfect, apart from the huge annual payment fee. I guess when you are earning enough money $450 doesn't matter. I do like the automatic $25k rewards after you spend 2 grand in this first month. However, I have seen cards that offer you large rewards for spending in the first few months which do not have a yearly fee. I also don't understand why the balance must be paid in full each month. What's the point of having a credit card if you can't carry a balance? Although the rewards seem great, I think there is more bad to this card than good.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: American Express Gold card really does set the standard for cards. This is literally the best credit card I've ever had. I could live without the fee ($125 a year, wow!) but I think that's just something that you're going to have to live with when it comes to credit cards nowadays. A friend of mine told me that if you called them they could waive the fee but I haven't tried it yet. I moved on to this card after using The Matrix card for a while and there has been a night and day difference. Not only am I happy with it but American Express has always been responsive whenever I call them. I hope your experiences are the same.
I like the fact that the card has no interest rate for the 1st 15 months. Also, the fact that is doesn't have that many fees. I like the bonus miles. the only down fall is the high APR.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: While the idea of not having to submit to a credit check is nice for those in such a position, the card is not the one you want from American Express. They have another card that can also be requested online called Bluebird. In fact, you cannot have a Serve account and a Bluebird account. The Bluebird account has higher account limits for transactions and balances, plus most of the same benefits as the Serve account (I believe the Serve account balance limit is $2500 in contrast to $100,000 for the Bluebird account). Bluebird is offered through some partnership with Walmart. If you like the idea of an American Express prepaid card, skip Serve and go with Bluebird.

This card seems alright, however the 75 dollar a year fee seems a little steep for simply owning a credit card. Other cards offer rewards and high credit limits without having to charge such a large fee. I also am not fond of of "reward dollars" as rewards. On top of the fact that these rewards can only be used to pay your credit card bill, the amount you have to spend in order to reap any benefits seems high. I would much prefer air mile rewards that other credit cards offer. The no starting interest rate for 15 months, however, does appeal to me.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The Hilton Credit Card is a card that packs a punch. True it's for good credit, but it's not an unobtainable card. If you like to travel a lot and don't want to stay in motels, this is the perfect card for you. Hilton is one of the top brands in Hotel accommodations so you know you won't be disappointed. The best part about this card is that there is no annual fee. A similar card, the Capital One Venture Rewards card has a $59 annual fee after the first year. Free is always better in my book. With the Hilton Card you get 3 points for every $1.00 spent and 5 points for every $1.00 spent at a restaurant or eligible supermarket. Plus if you spend just $750 in your first 3 months you get a bonus 40,000 points. You get complimentary Silver Status at all their locations just for having the card. It really is a great card for travelers who won't have to worry about another sleepless night in an unknown hotel. Use your card like you would any card and you will rack up the points in no time to know that you are going to be traveling in luxury. For any traveler or family that likes to vacation, I highly recommend this card.

This is simply one of the best cards on the market, hands down. Not only is their customer service super friendly and legit helpful, but their annual fee the first year is waived and only 95$ a year after that! You simply can not beat that plain and simple. Other banks charge you the first year and jack up the annual fee to above 200$, not with this bank! I also like that late fees are only 35$. With big banks now a days they charge you an arm and a leg for being late and it is very costly!

The American Express Green Card was one of the first cards we had when we moved to the U.S., so maybe that's why we were not fully aware of any major benefits. It was nice that they offered it to us when we had not yet built credit (it's really the only reason why we accepted it) but once we'd built some credit the $100 annual fee just wasn't worth it. So all in all, I guess both sides benefited from the relationship and then it was over. I am kind of glad that we don't have it anymore however, it doesn't carry as much of a status symbol as it used to and let's be honest, many small businesses don't accept them.

Of all the prepaid credit card options that I considered, the Bluebird Card by American Express was the most appealing for a number of reasons. First, the process of securing a card could be completed from the comfort of my home office computer station, and the actual card arrived in my mailbox roughly one week later. The activation process was simple, and then the benefits began to really unfold. Keeping accurate records is as simple as sitting down at any computer station and logging into my account. The security features of the login process are also reassuring. The Bluebird Card allows me to make direct deposits from employers, including many of the online monetary transfer options such as PayPal and government issued checks. There are no fees for using the card, unlike many bank account debit cards that can be accompanied by fees or charges associated with the account itself. Depositing actual cash money in my Bluebird account is as easy as a trip to Wal-Mart.
