The only potential fee associated with the card is for ATM withdrawals but that is waived with a direct deposit setup, and allows for free access to my money at any MoneyPass ATM machine. The card has an account number and routing number that are a checking account for transfer purposes, but Bluebird also has the option of setting up “sub-accounts” for family members or friends, (who receive their own card controlled by the official cardholder), and also has a relatively new feature referred to as a “SetAside Account”. This is a separate place within your account page, which is like having your own savings account right at your fingertips. For prepaid credit cards, I am thoroughly elated with my Bluebird American Express Card, and would recommend it to anyone who needs to rebuild or establish a credit history.

I understand the Platinum Card from American Express has a lot of perks but a annual fee of $450 really blows my mind. I would hope if it costs you $450 annually it would provide plenty of overwhelming perks to cancel out the annual fee. I believe that is quite high compared to other credit cards. Also, your balance has to be paid in full each month, a big negative. I don't really see the point of this card unless you travel very frequently and can take full advantage of the reward points. The only plus I really liked about this card is the entertainment benefits. I would enjoy being able to get advanced tickets but it says by invitation only. Another red flag for me. I also prefer Visa and Mastercard over American express, just a personal preference. Just because it is perceived as elite or high end doesn't make it a great card. There is no credit limit which is a positive, but I don't think it outweighs all the negatives.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: My American Express Gold card is the only card I couldn't live without. It's not for everyone and it isn't easy to qualify for but it is definitely a great card. There isn't a stated interest rate because they choose your rate personally. With my credit history I got a great rate at 8 percent for the life of the card. The annual fee of 125 has been around for as long as I can remember. They do waive the fee the first year and you do get the option to cancel the card if you're not satisfied with it. If you take into account the yearly fee and the low interest rate it cost me about the same as my Bank of America Premium card does. The best part of the American Express card is the customer service, hands down the most helpful credit card company I've ever dealt with.

The American Express Prepaid Card is a useful option that in reality supplants a debit card, but provides other features since it is actually categorized as a credit card when using it for purchases. The AMEX Prepaid Card is almost identical to the Bluebird card that is offered at local Wal-Mart stores in the name of American Express also. One primary advantage the American Express Prepaid Card has over the Bluebird Card concerns the available alternatives to deposit or withdrawal funds. With fewer restrictions on places for withdrawal, the holder of the American Express Prepaid Card has a slightly better range of available options to get at their money.


Another appealing feature, although rather limited in scope, is the single free ATM withdrawal available on the AMEX Prepaid Card, whereas the Bluebird Card does not offer any free ATM withdrawals unless the user has a predetermined direct deposit in place from an employer or governmental agency. Both cards offer online management of the cardholder account, and the American Express Prepaid Card may lead to an invitation from American Express to apply for a standard charge card.

The charge card version of the Blue credit card, the American Express Green Card allows you to have some of the benefits of a credit card but requires the balance be paid in full each month. Better than a debit if you don't have funds right now, and without the interest rates associated with a credit card, the Green Card is good if you travel frequently. With its double points on purchases made through American Express Travel and the ability to redeem points in the same site, you could quickly rack up points if you fly a lot. However, the redemption options beyond this are limited. Additionally, while there's no annual fee the first year, the $95 every year after is a bit rough.

The Blue from American Express card offers good value at a reasonable rate. With its initial bonus of 10,000 points for 1000 dollars spent within the first three months, it gets you off and running on using its rewards system. There's a wide range of ways you can spend the points you accrue, and the double rate accrual on purchases made through their online travel site is good if you're a frequent traveler. With reasonable interest rates and no annual fee, the card compares favorably to others in its class. The 0% interest rate on the first 15 months of purchases is also extremely good. I like this card quite a bit.

I like how the card has no interest rate for the first fifteeen months. However there are numerous other great things about this card as well. One of my main reasons is that it doesnt have an annual fee. Another great upside is that you can earn up to one point for every dollar spent. So that gives you a way to rack up points easily. Amex is a great company but one downside to the card is that its not accepted at everywhere. Another thing I dont like is when the apr does kick in its kind of steep!!
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: This card is good because there is no annual fee. Also, if you spend a lot each year, $20K plus, the extra perks are pretty good. I've actually used the baggage insurance plan before, and it worked out pretty well, so if you're a frequent traveler, this would be a pretty good card. I also had a Capital One No Hassles Travel Card, but only really ended up using it to get the 2% cash back on travel purchases. The Hilton card really does go farther if you travel a lot. Another thing I like about the Hilton card is that there are no blackout dates for hotel stays, so it's nice to take advantage of during peak times.

They do not check your credit, therefore you could probably still get one if you have not established credit yet. I have established credit, but need to open two more accounts to go up a level in my rating. I do not, however, wish to add any more bills or spend any more money on interest. This could potentially be what I was looking for. It would save me money on checks whenever I send money to people. This card does not charge for inactivity, which is good for a conservative spender like me. Using it does not mean paying more money than the amount of the actual purchase because this is not a credit card. I think I will apply for this, as it looks like a really good plan.

The American Express prepaid card is an amazing card. It spends like money but works like membership. I think it is amazing that there aren’t any fees. I know other prepaid cards that charge a monthly fee which is not ideal when using cash to load the card. This card comes with a 24 hour a day customer service number that allows you to get assistance when you need it. This is a great card for young teens as well as a parent can get an account and just share a card with a child. This helps limit their spending and track purchases. Since this card comes with the guarantee that no fraudulent charges will be charged it gives you the peace of mind that your money will be safe!

This credit card is beneficial for frequent travelers only. The reward points seem to be only for travel related rewards which is a big limitation of the card. There are companies providing credit cards with 5 X cashback like discover which this card doesn't provide. There is an annual fees for this card which most of the companies and my credit card company do not charge. The required credit score is also excellent to get approved for this card. My credit card requires average score for approval. However I liked that there are no blackout dates or seat restrictions when you pay with your points. Overall this card offer is not attractive.

The Blue from American Express card is nice if you need to make a large purchase to pay off, as they offer a 15 month interest-free period. To further the incentive, they offer 10,000 points if you charge $1,000 of eligible purchases to the card within the first three months. However, after the 15 month period, their interest rates are quite high, with the lowest offered being 15.24%. If you are smart and make a plan to pay off any purchases before the 15 months are up, then this card will be quite useful for you. Just watch out for the high interest.

This is a fantastic offer. No interest for 15 months? I've never seen a deal like this. The points you earn are substantially more valuable than most other card's plans, and there is no limit and they don't expire. Once the regular rate kicks in, it is about on par with my other cards. I can save hundreds by transferring all my balances to it and paying them off during the 0% period. I am applying.https://wallethub.com/d/blue-american-express-credit-card-41c/

I like that The Platinum Card from American Express has so many perks associated with it. One of my favorites, is the premium travel benefits. Traveling is stressful enough, but being a member of the Priority Pass Select means receiving preference treatments at airports. While everybody else have to wait at the gates, member of the Priority Pass select can wait at a VIP lounge, which is really cool, especially if you have a long connecting flight.


What I don’t like about the credit card is that you have to pay the full balance every month, which can be good or bad, depending on the situation.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The American Express Gold Card isn't for everyone. It is an exclusive card where excellent credit is required. But if you are in great standing and want a card that delivers, this is the card for you. It is truly one of the elite cards on the market, and there is no fee for the first year. The best part about this card is the unlimited purchasing power it affords you. There is no limit and if you are ever in a crunch you know that you have exclusive access to credit. The rewards focus more on exclusivity. They have an unheralded Extended Warranty and Return Protection for your purchases. My favorite aspect of the card is booking my travel through their Gold Hotel Collection. You immediately get a $75 hotel credit. Sure there are other cards like the Capital One Quicksilver which are comparable. But they don't offer the perks that extended travelers like myself need. They tend to focus more on the cash back as opposed to the elite benefits a frequent traveler with great credit like myself needs. If you travel a lot, need purchase power, and are interested in a great card, do yourself a favor and give the American Express Gold Card a chance. You won't be disappointed.

The best part about this card is the lack of fees. You can also get 0% APR for the first 15 months. Which a significantly long time for 0% APR. There is a cash advance rate is the average amount such as the other cards on the market. Another plus to this card is that you can earn one point for every dollar you spend. The best part is the points can be put to good use to rewards such as traveling. American Express is a great card and company to be associated with. One issue you may encounter is that everyone does not accept American Express cards. Other than that enjoy!
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: What I like about the American Express Serve prepaid card is that there is no fee to activate. In the past, every prepaid card I have ever used has had a substantial activation fee. What I don’t like is the ATM fees. Now, to use an ATM, there is no charge IF that ATM is within the Moneypass system AND you’re enrolled in direct deposit. However, for one thing, the whole reason I wanted a prepaid card was to not have to use my bank as a backup – when the cash (intended for fun shopping only!) was gone, it was gone. Just like using cash, but with the ease of a card. I use prepaid cards as gifts and for myself instead of gift cards, because they can be used anywhere. But, it costs me $2.00 to use the American Express serve card at an ATM because I don’t want to be enrolled in direct deposit. Plus, there are almost no Moneypass ATMs in my area! That’s why I’m not using this card anymore!

Awesome for travel, especially with using and acquiring points! I really like the idea of being able to have auto rental insurance too. And wherever you go, there is sure to be a Hilton nearby that you can stay at and redeem some of those points!

APR isn't as high as other cards, but the rewards aren't exactly the greatest either. I would prefer flyer miles as opposed to "reward dollars", but in any case it's a reward that can always be used towards something!
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I like that there is no annual fee, as well as the bonus miles... the only ouch is the high apr and foreign fees! Make sure you make your payments on time!
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: I actually really like this card, I get cash back for spending normally so I just put all my spending on it and it eventually adds up. I earned $400 this past year. I also have used some of their other guarantees to help save me money and get me out of a tricky situation. I purchased a brand new laptop and within a few weeks had ruined it. I filed a claim and Amex reimbursed me within a few weeks. I use this wherever they accept Amex. I have never had any problems with the card or customer service that I can recall and I have had this since 2004. I have never been tempted to leave this card for better offers because I trust Amex and know I am getting a good product. I also pay my balance every month so I don't pay any fees I just get cash back.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The American Express green card is geared toward wealthy people who can pay their charge card off each month and want to earn rewards. There's no preset spending limit, so these cards can be dangerous. The first year is great because there isn't an annual fee, but every year after that you find yourself paying $95. You do get the benefit of the Global Assist Hotline which provides 24/7 emergency assistance when traveling more than 100 miles from home and roadside assistance. That has value. Rewards are pretty easy to earn and flexible. You earn about one point on the dollar spent and you can earn 2X points when you use American Express Travel. The points also transfer over to 17 Frequent Flyer programs, which is pretty cool. I gave it a two because it's not a card that most people would qualify for.

The Blue American Express Credit Card offers a variety of good rewards. I really like the initial bonus 10,000 points when used for purchases of at least $1,000 in the first three months. I also really like that the travel points are doubled when booking online through the American Express Travel website. There is also no redeeming limit, which is really nice because I can save up those points for something bigger that I want versus having to cash out my points on small items. I also like that this Credit Card is accepted outside of the United States. What I don’t like is the high rates that go along with this card – with a minimum interest rate of 15.24, it seems a bit steep. I know my Visa Credit Card interest rate is lower than that.

The American Express Gold Card has interesting and unique features. I think the hotel discount is a quite enticing one that might make it easier to find an affordable stay. The baggage insurance is also something worth looking into but on the other, the foreign transaction fee does not seem very good. I know that some people love American Express but I find that it is limited in the places I would be able to use it. Also, I keep getting offers for this in the mail to the point where it is excessive. I tried applying for the card but it was denied. I wanted another card to increase my spending power for emergencies. All this even though I have credit in the upper 700-800 range. I still prefer using my Chase Freedom card where I get visible cash back every month. However if you are interested in the features that this card has to offer it might be good to try to apply for it.

I am now having the Gold Delta SkyMiles Credit Card from American Express for five months. This credit card is a very good option when you frequently consider flying with Delta Airlines. Also, when you spend 500 dollars during the first five months, you get 50 dollars back. Moreover, the card holder enjoys having the first bag free on Delta flights.

However, I had a problem trying to register this card online, the registration process failed several times for no obvious reason, and I had to call the customer service for around four times to get it resolved. Another problem, the online card console is not always up-to-date. It always tells about the next bill too late, about one week after the end of the previous bill date. Overall, I recommend having this card for Delta fans. It is a great option to have.
department: Delta SkyMiles® Gold Business American Express Card

content: There are a handful of advantages to the American Express Platinum Credit Card, especially for travelers who can take advantage of their annual $200 incentive for flight fees. The "VIP" treatment this card gives you when purchasing event tickets is also really neat, especially if you're a concert dweller that loves getting front and center. This card is definitely made for a thrill seeker and the 25k reward points in the beginning is just about enough to make even the fuddiest of duddies want to seek some thrills. The fees aren't much higher than the competitors and the interest rate is also comparable,however; the annual fee is incredibly high, but understandable for someone wanting a "prestige" credit card.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: I always have enjoyed using my American Express Prepaid card. The design on it is great, and it works just as well as any other American Express card, but without the credit part! The card being prepaid was a huge advantage, because it kept me from overspending. The only thing I didn't like was the fact that a lot of merchants and retailers don't accept American Express cards. Other than that, this is my favorite card. No fees, no hassles, just convenience. I hope to someday own another American Express card. Their customer service team is unbeatable, and always there to help you.

I love the Blue Sky credit card. It's a decent credit card on its own with 17.24% interest rate, which is about average for a lot of cards. The cash advance rate is also high at 25 percent like every other card on the market. But the Blue Sky is a step above most with it's great point system. You earn one point for every dollar you spend like every other point card but you don't have to spend your points on some lame gift card, you can use it to travel. I use my card all year long, pay of the balance every month and redeem my points for a trip at the end of the year. So far this card has served me well and it even replaced my Bank America Travel Reward card that only gave me a hundred dollars for every ten thousand dollars I spent. Altogether this is a great card if you love to travel and want to save a little money.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The Hilton Credit Card is good if you are traveling a lot. I use this card when I travel across the United States. This card in my opinion is very helpful to me because I can receive points when I use the Credit card which turns into a one free night at the hotel. This credit card does not have Annual Fee which is very good because most of the other credit cards have. Also it is very easy to make payments on the website to pay the monthly payments. Overall, I am very happy with this credit card.

I really like the sound of the American Express Serve card. I’ve had credit card troubles in the past so this type of prepaid card is exactly what I am looking for. I especially enjoy the idea of getting a bonus just for loading it up twice with direct deposits. That’s a great deal and something I would absolutely be interested in. No fee for ATM withdrawals is an attractive service, especially combined with the online ability to email money without needing a separate bank involved. Being able to monitor my activity anywhere with the app will help me not make mistakes with the card.

For me it's hard to overlook the 75 dollar yearly fee to use this card, and the fact that getting it requires near perfect credit. Those are big draw backs. BUT if you are able to get the card and afford the fee, it offers some great rewards. The cash back for gas and groceries, along with the $150 back if you make $1000 in purchases is nice. Overall the Blue Cash Preferred card from American Express is decent card if you can get it, it's just hard to get.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The American Express Platinum Card is a must-have for frequent travelers. The reward points and perks cardholders receive are pretty awesome. The lounges available to cardholders and the $200 statement credit for use toward baggage fees and other travel expenses are really useful for business travelers. I have another rewards card (Chase Disney Visa) and it doesn’t even compare to the perks associated with the Amex Platinum Card. The annual fee is quite high, but is pretty much offset by the rewards you receive when you use the card. The fact that there is no foreign transaction fee is also very convenient for travelers, making this the ideal card for anyone who frequently goes overseas. There is no pre-set spending limit, allowing for even more flexibility.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The American Express Gold Card is an overall great card. It is very easy to use and is accepted in many, many places. In fact, there hasn't been a place I have gone where it has not been accepted. One of the things I liked about this card was the zero dollar introductory fee! Wow. That was one bonus that I have not seen in many other places. There are so many benefits to having this card. Having an American Express is a privilege nowadays and I can easily see why. The only downside I have found with this card is that I have to pay off that balance in full at the end of each month. Although it does keep me on my toes and keeps my credit report up, it is a con for me.

I love my American Express Prepaid Card! I primarily use it for shopping online. Since it's a prepaid card, I don't have to worry as much about someone misusing my information. I like that it has so many convenient load options, including by phone, online, by direct deposit, with a bank account, or with cash. When I need to make a withdrawal, I benefit from the fact that I get a free one each month. Unlike most other prepaid cards, the American Express Prepaid Card doesn't have activation or monthly user fees which is very convenient. American Express is always a cool card to have and whenever I have any questions or problems, I can call their customer support 24/7.

I thought that the terms of the card were great. The fact that here is no fees for the card to be uses is nice. That will make it much more convenient to give card to my kids. It is a great alternative to sending them with cash that is much easier to lose. Not too long ago I was issued a pre-paid card from Citi bank. The card had fees every time that you would go to swipe it. It was $0.50 for a debit transaction and $3.50 for a credit transaction. I felt like those were unnecessary amounts to be charged. The American Express Prepaid card had almost no cons.

I think the Blue American Express card is great for the times that I want to travel. I like that it has no annual fee although I'm a bit worried that they may extract that money in other ways. I like the idea of getting 10,000 points by charging $1,000 within the first three months. The best thing is definitely the fact that I can use it for more than just airfare; I can use the card to cover car rental, hotel/hostel bookings, and just about everything else. The regular rate isn't bad although the cash advance rate is kind of high. But then again, I would be using it mainly to make reservations so that really isn't too much of a problem. American Express is a very prestigious card and it always looks good in my wallet.

I like how the American Express Green Card earns you points even though it is not a credit card. This is a great deal for a card that is used like a debit, you pay off the balance each month in full and you get miles and points to use for vacation. For people that need to get credit started, this card is great because you could most likely get this approved with no credit. This card reminds me of my first "secured" credit card, that card however did not earn me points or give me rewards, it simply built my credit. I would recommend this card for people who cannot get a standard mileage or points credit card.

I love this card for the most part. I like that i can use it pretty much anywhere nowadays. There is a pretty high yearly fee which I do not like. They dont charge this fee after the first year but it's still a high fee to hold a credit card. I do like how you are required to pay off your balance every month. It helps my credit rating and it makes sure I don't go further into debt. Both are perks in my opinion. If you travel a ton, which I don't usually then this card will come in handy. I don't use it much because I really don't have much reason too. I got it for a vacation initially and now it just sort of sits around and then I have to pay that silly yearly fee on it. I should cancel the card but I don't want to affect my credit rating.

Lets start with the basics of Blue Cash's Preferred credit card, first you must have great credit, and secondly you must be willing to pay 75$ a year to keep using this, but with that out of the way lets start. This reward card has some very promising rates associated with it like 6% of food products, 3% on gas and shopping goods, and 1% on everything else. The real winning feature here is the 6% on groceries, everyone needs to buy them, and 6% cannot be beat by any other card hands down. The rewards money you get can be automatically used on your credit statement lowering your full cost. There are not many cons besides the annual cost and credit required, and with that in mind I would say to give this card a further checking out before you pursue it and enjoy your new card!!
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The Blue Sky card from American Express seems like a pretty decent rewards card. The points you gain is a bit sad at just 1:1$, but there is no redeem or earn limit so you can rack up tons of points over time! There is no intro rate for purchases and balance transfers which is always good, but in addition to that there is also no annual fee which is just icing on the cake. The main downside to this card is redeeming your points has a somewhat sad conversion ratio which is for every 7500 points you get 100$ a hotel/car rental/cruise/plane ticket. As a recluse I do not travel much and prefer my points going towards tangible things, but for those who enjoy vacations this could be quite nice!
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The American Express Serve is similar to the green dot cards out there but this one is much better. With green dot you have balance fees, and monthly fees if you do not have a certain amount on your card, but this isnt the case for this card as Pretty much anything you want to do will be free (except buying things of course). There really is not anything bad to say about this card, and only good things should come from this. It is useful to give as a gift as it can be used almost anywhere and there is no risk of going over a limit as its prepaid! This is an awesome card and I highly recommend it.

The Hilton Credit Card is great if you are a frequent business or leisure traveler. Earning points should be easy if this is you. It's a great feature where you can earn free rooms, especially if you plan on being on the road a lot. However, if not, it can take a while to get enough points for a free room. It would take spending over $700 with Hilton, just to get a free room, as Hilton says as few as 5,000 points can get you a room. So if you're not a frequent traveler, look for other cards that fit your needs. But if you find yourself in a Hilton Hotel often, it makes too much sense to register for this card.

I like to use Blue American Express as my go-to travel credit card because it employs Global Assist, which enabled me to find a bilingual Japanese private investigator when I took a trip to Japan to locate my long-lost best friend. When going overseas to a country in which the populace does not speak English fluently, this card will help you connect the dots with banks, hospitals, and lawyers that can communicate with you in English. Should you get lost or your items be stolen, American Express will connect you similarly to consulates, wiring services, and passport agencies. This card is indispensable to me.

The american express prepaid card is a great prepaid card because it does not have fees like the other prepaid cards have. This is mainly good if you want to give your younger sibling who do not have credit cards. They can use this to buy things online, just like a credit card. What's also great is that they do not have a foreign transaction fees like the other prepaid cards have. If the card gets stolen, you do not have to worry about the money that you have in the card. Your money is well protected by american express and you just have to let them know about the current situation. Overall a great prepaid card.

The American Express Green Card is a decent option if, for some reason, you don't want a credit card. As it is a charge card, you must pay off your balance in full each month or incur a fee of 2.99% with a minimum charge of $35. The only benefit you get from using this card is points for American Express Travel. You can find better travel benefits from a rewards credit card, including higher point rewards and extras like travel insurance and car insurance, neither of which this card provide. In addition to all the limitations of having an American Express card (which isn't accepted nearly as many place as Visa or Mastercard, especially overseas), after the first year you're hit with a $95 annual fee.

The Blue American Express card is a decent card. The interest can be on the low side for most people. The cash advance is high like every other card out there. The point system is really impressive though. Compared to my Visa credit card the Blue card racks up points much quicker. There is also no cap on the amount of points you can earn in the month unlike my Visa. The point system is also really simple to understand and every thing is laid out right where you can see it. Altogether I found this to be the better card and it eventually replaced my main card.

The American Express Gold Card seems nice but it seems like it isn't meant for everyone. I do not like the fact that there is a significantly expensive yearly fee, nor do I like that your balance has to be paid in full every month. I couldn't afford that. The Chase Freedom card, on the other hand, does not have a yearly fee, nor do you have to have your entire balanced paid in full each month. That card also has low APR. While the perks of being an American Express card member are nice, they are just not feasible for me and most likely a large chunk of Americans.

This was my first card from American Express and it did not disappoint me. I'm thinking of upgrading to the Preferred version, but for now I have the Everyday, and it carries some pretty good cash back rates. I've used the 2% rate at department stores around holidays and birthdays for gifts, and of course the 3% on groceries is incredibly easy to take advantage of. I think the only disadvantage is that you can't redeem the cash into your bank account, but statement credit is always nice to use later, and the reward categories are permanent. This is my grocery card.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The Platinum Card from American Express is one of the most elite credit cards on the market today. It gets a lot of bad rep because of the annual fee, but that's from people who can't understand all the benefits. Just for spending 2,000 over your first 3 months you get 25,000 reward points which is more than enough to compensate for the fee. This card is NOT for everyone, but if you do have excellent credit and want the prestige AND the benefits of a rewarding card this is for you. A similar card is the Visa Black card, but the annual fee there is $495 and they don't have the 24/7 concierge service which makes the Platinum Card from American Express unique and special. If you are in the mood for a high end high benefit card then this card is perfect for you.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: The Blue Cash Preferred Credit Card from American Express is my go-to credit card. It offers 6% cash back on groceries, 3% cash back on department store purchases/ gas purchases, and 1% back on everything else. There is a $75 a year fee, but you can make that back fast on grocery purchases. The cash back can be used as a statement credit or you can use the money to purchase household items through American Express. I have never had any major issues using this card anywhere American Express is accepted, even aboard. Every time I have called customer service they have been prompt and courteous to my inquiries.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The American Express Serve card looks like a great prepaid card. You can't go wrong with no activation fee and no monthly fee. Those are big ones. If you have direct deposit, you can use it for free at ATMs, too. This is unlike the READYdebit Visa prepaid card, which has a 10 dollar activation fee off the top, and then a 10 dollar a month fee. It also costs $2.25 for each transaction with an ATM. What card makes more sense to you? While both have free signature/pin transaction fees, it's evident that the American Express Serve prepaid card hits it out of the park in terms of a great prepaid card to have.

If you have an excellent credit score, the Blue Cash Preferred from American Express looks like a winner. There is an intro rate of 0% interest for 15 months and you can earn up to 6% back on grocery store purchases. This looks like a good deal for a family who spends a pretty penny on their grocery bill. The regular APR falls between 12.99 and 21.99%. If you can keep your interest rate on the lower end, that seems like a fair APR. The drawback is that it is variable. That can sometimes be a burden if you are not careful with your finances. This card definitely beats the Capital One Platinum card I own by quite a wide margin. My card currently has an APR of 24.9% and I don't get any rewards points like the Blue Cash offers, but I got to design how my card looks, so take that Blue Cash!. If I had the credit score to do so, I would definitely consider this card.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: Blue Sky by American Express is a great card. 0% APR for 15 months is a pretty long time! Initial welcome bonuses are also pretty hard to beat. No annual fee is also refreshing, as most cards now have big annual fees that add up. I'd say my main gripe with this card is that it's an American Express card, so it's not accepted in many places still. Had this been a VISA card, I may have given it 5 stars. Interest is decent, and earning 1 point for every purchase ($1 per point) is a great way to rack up points.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content:
The Hilton Credit Card is a good choice if you are a business or leisure traveler and spend a lot of time staying in hotels. You can accumulate points quickly on hotel stays and you still get a decent amount of points for restaurants, gas, and grocery purchases. The 40,000 bonus points is a nice extra to start out with and the APR is pretty comparable to most other cards out there.

Usually hotel rewards come with a bunch of restrictions on when and where you can redeem them, but there are no blackout dates on the redemption of your HHilton points associated with this card. It also provides you with rental car and travel insurance, which every traveler knows are essential. The best part? No annual fee.

The fact that there is no interest or annual fee for the 1st year is nice. I never knew there was a substantial difference between a "charge" and a "Credit" card... Honestly other than the immediate convenience in the very short term IE not having cash on you, I think the fact that this card has no spending limit AND is a charge card so the full balance has to be paid down each month makes it potentially dangerous to the impulsive, but then again you need excellent credit so It is unlikely to get into the hands of people who are prone to that sort of thing. I think the points transfer program to frequent flyer miles and the roadside assistance is good though.

The American Express Premier Rewards Gold Card is a true step up from the regular Gold Card. Yes, the annual fee is higher than the regular card, however the name 'premier rewards' holds true - each reward category is improved over the regular, and you earn even more reward points as part of of the excellent Membership Rewards program. These points can be used for gift cards, plane tickets, hotel bookings, or shopping online. You also get improved customer service and perks that only American Express offers. From what I understand, Gold and Platinum members get improved customer service compared to, say, one of their prepaid cards.
department: Premier Rewards Gold Card from American Express

content: Blue from American Express is a really great card with lots of benefits and it's accepted virtually everywhere. There are so many perks that you don't even think about with the card. The generic stuff is standard as far as late fees and apr go, but it's great that there is no overlimit fee when you are in a crunch. It's got a much better apr at 27.24 than a similar chase sapphire preferred. It also has a 25 day grace compared to the sapphires 21 and it has online responses where the sapphire doesn't. Plus every dollar you spend you can get up to 2 points and they start you out with 10,000 with only 1,000 in purchases over your first 3 months. You can airline travel with no blackout dates with your points. Definitely a card I love and recommend to anyone looking for a new card.

American Express Prepaid Card is a wonderful solution to not having a bank account. I love the fact that there is no monthly fee that is something very unusual now a days from prepaid cards they all want to make their money off of the monthly fees. There is no sign up fees and no cancellation fees which is also wonderful. Another thing that amazes me is there is no transaction fees seems like the only fee this card will hit you with is a fee to withdraw money which is fine by me, I rarely ever go to an ATM and withdraw money. They have free customer support which is also another big plus. It's American Express not some fly by night company, you can trust this card. Practically every retail spot excepts this in every country you're safe with this card anywhere you go.

I like the 0% rate for 15 months on this card. It is one of the longest intro periods I have heard of. The regular rate is kind of high. I also like that if you make $1,000 in purchases You earn 7,500 points ($100 in travel credit). The balance transfer fee is also advantageous for any cards (which are all of them for me) that have an interest rate over 3% (I see mention of no interest on transfers). I believe I will apply for this and transfer my other cards balances (which have interests of 14 to 21%) to it and use the Blue Sky American Express card exclusively for all charges where possible for the next 15 months.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The American Express Serve looks like another good prepaid card. There is no activation fee or monthly maintenance fee. Moreover, there is no customer support fee for either automated or live support. Compare this to the Upside prepaid which charges 2 dollars for live and .99 cents for automated support. Also, there is a monthly maintenance fee of 4.95 if your account drops below 500 dollars. Another good thing about the American Express Serve is that there is no inactivity fee. The Western Union American Express prepaid is another good card, but it charges a 2.95 dollar inactivity fee after 120 days of non-use. I also like that there is an option of no ATM fees if you enroll in their Money Pass Network. The out of network fee will be 2 dollars. I think it is probably worth investigating how frequently you would be able to use their network. If you can avoid ATM fees for the most part, this would only sweeten the deal with this card.

The Blue Cash Preferred from American Express card is an alright credit card. The 75 dollar annual fee is really high in my opinion. It does offer a good deal on money back though. The 6 percent on supermarket shopping is a pretty great deal. Don't take this card overseas though. The foreign transaction fee is 2.7 percent, which is not very good. There are plenty of other cards for that. I have the Citi Diamond Preferred credit Card and it has no annual fee, at all. It also has very similar reward system. The 75 dollar fee for this card is the big downer for me. Plus, you need really high credit score to get it. It's really too much for a card that is not that great. I would not recommend this credit card to anyone really.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: This is one of my favorite cards. It was really hard to apply to ( I got rejected once). The reason I got this card was that "airline cards" had a way too expensive fee attach to them. Also this card's foreign exchange fee is lower than most banks, since most banks start at 3%. The only reason I got this card was my family and I had a big travel year. We wanted to get the most value out of it. The only thing I did not like is that it is on "American Express" and I could not use it at some restaurants. So I always have 2 brands of credit cards with me, Amex and Visa. Also I find when I use this card at their hotels, I get really amazing customer service. Time to time, they offer free upgrades or they really listen to my "special request" section.

I like that Blue by American Express has a 15 month introductory period with 0% financing. My current credit card's, a Visa offered by Pay Pal, introductory period was much shorter. It only lasted for 6 months and then the rate jumped up to 14%. What I do not like about the Blue card is how high the regular rate jumps after the intro period. My experience is that if it says 15.24% - 20.24% it is almost always going to be much closer to the higher rate than the lower. I also do not like that they charge a balance transfer fee of 3%. I do really like about the Blue card that the points do not expire. That is a nice amenity. In the past I have had cards where the points expired and I was not able to use them for one reason or another. All in all this looks like a great choice for a card.

I like the fact that there is zero annual fee for the first year. For some people they do not like the fact they have to pay their entire balance. I think that this allows you to be able to control your spending, because you know what to keep your limit each month. It will hopefully cut down on the need to splurge, because you know that you will have to pay back the entire balance and there are no interest charges. I love the fact that you can transfer points to your flying balance if you are a frequent flyer. The more points means the less that you will have to pay when purchasing a plane ticket. I also love roadside assistance. My account now prepaid visa does not offer a lot of these features. I would say that this is a great card to have.

American Express Prepaid Card is a great card to have. If do not prefer not to have credits cards and also like to purchase on online or even in stores. You can also use this card for direct deposit if you do not have a bank account. Also there are no fees when using this card and also you get one free ATM withdrawal a month. In my opinion, this is a bad because some people prefer to use this features more frequently, unless you are willing to pay the penalty fee that costs two dollars. I barely use this feature since I only use it to make purchases online. Adding money to the prepaid card is very simple and easy to do. Overall I am happy to be using this card and I never had any problems with it.

I simply love the Blue Cash Everyday Credit Card. First off, I love the 0% intro APR for the first 15 months and I also love the no annual fee part too. The interest rate is 12.99% after the 15 months so pretty average.The late fees are pretty standard but I wish they didn't have them though. What this card is really good at though is the rewards. You get 3% back at the grocery store and 2% back on gas. This is stuff that most people are going to get anyways. Might as well get a little cash back on it. Every thing else is 1% cash back. With a 100 dollar signing bonus you beat this card. I would really recommend this card to anyone to help get a little money back on the stuff your going to spend anyways.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: Personally, I don't see a reason why one has to apply for the platinum card from American Express. The annual fee is simply exorbitant. Yes, maybe its a prestige to own one, but those $450 would look great inside my wallet than against my name! Its good for ones who spend a lot, look out for premium services and purchase regularly, but for an average conservative buyer like me, there is no real necessity to go for the platinum card. There is absolutely no cash back, which even a basic card would provide. Maybe its simply because of the annual fee that am not able to highlight anything positive about the card!
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: This card is the epitome of an excessive credit card. The exorbitant annual fee coupled with the lack of a limit just seems unnecessary to anybody who isn't exceedingly rich. This card provides no benefits; outside of the lack of a limit, when compared to an average Capital One Rewards card. Everything this card does, my current credit card does, without the excessive fee or ridiculously high credit rating required. Furthermore, American Express is often not accepted at local retailers; making this card even less valuable. Unless you're a famous socialite, or a rich CEO; this card is not for you.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: I am a fan of using the American Express Gold Card and have been a member for years now. Having to pay off my balance in full every month may be seen as a negative for some, but I enjoy the simplicity it offers towards managing my expenses, and this way I don't have to ever worry about high APRs. The annual fee being only $125 dollars is very reasonable, and being that you have no annual fee at all the first year of use is quite a good deal. Though it is worth noting that the foreign transaction fee at 2.7% is a little high, and it frustrating when I go to an establish and only learn upon paying that they do not accept AMEX cards. Overall a great a experience though. I much prefer it to similar cards, such as the Capital One Quicksilver Credit Card.

The American Express Green Card offers a great rewards program for those with the appropriate credit. This card has extensive online options for keeping track of finances and managing your card, which is a great feature that can be useful to almost anyone. It is also nice that there is no annual fee for the first year, and that reward points are earned for every dollar that you spend with the card! The card also has no preset spending limit, which is nice for making larger purchases. A 24/7 emergency hotline for assistance rounds out this balanced, beneficial rewards card.

The Blue credit card from American Express is worth it, although you have to have great credit to have it. The best thing about this card is the 15 month, 0 percent interest introductory rate; this is an abnormally long intro rate for a rewards card which makes it a great deal. The rewards program is also very beneficial, especially for someone that travels a lot; the 10,000 points initial bonus is a great start that offers incentive to the credit card user, and there are a fair amount of options that points can be used on. Try this card if you have the credit for it!

The Blue Cash Preferred Card from American Express is an excellent card. The first strength in this card is that you get a $150 bonus for starting up the card, which is excellent. You will earn 150 in reward points in the first 3 months if you spend $1,000. The reward bonuses can be redeemed as a statement on the credit, which is also excellent. You get 6% back for supermarkets, 3% for gas stations and select department stores, and 1% for other purchases. All in all, this card is excellent if you like to get the best bang for your buck.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I love this card because of it's Membership Rewards Program. I get rewarded with points that I can either use to purchase items at a special rate or exchange for a gift card to use at my favorite stores. There is a long list of participating stores to choose from for the gift cards, which is fantastic. I use my points to shop for the holidays or simply use the gift cards in place of a present. Further, what I love about having this card, is how vigilant AmEx is on suspicious activity. I have had them inform me that there had been such and such purchase on such and such day, to which I confirmed was not my doing. It was a 0 liability on my part. They took care of the rest.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: I have American Express clear since the beginning of 2013 and I am very happy with it. When I spend $2,500 I get $25 gift card. Clear does not have late fees, no balance transfer fees, no cash advance fees. Because I was a new customer I did not pay yearly card fee. I believe after 1 year later of service, they start charging you yearly fee. APR is very high with a rate of 26% but for me everything this card offers works very well. Unless they come up with a high amount of yearly card fee, I am willing to keep it and use it!
department: Clear from American Express Credit Card

content: I am very happy with my american express gold card i have had the card for many years now and use it for all of my business purchases. It is very convenient because it is accepted at most stores, online and worldwide so its great from travel. The thing i like most about this card is the rewards you can earn, rewards are great for getting free things such as hotel rooms, gift cards and trips. When it comes to the fees this card is free for the first year and only $125 a year after that which is an amazing deal. As i said early this card is great for travel not only for the rewards you can earn but there's only at 2.7% foreign transaction fee.

It’s always nice to see a credit card with some sort of reward or user incentive. In this particular case, the Blue Sky card from American Express has incentives that I wouldn’t likely use. I’m not an avid traveler; I rarely fly, and I almost never rent a car. It is likely that I would accumulate bonus points that I wouldn’t use. It is nice that they start you out with 7500 points; however, you must accumulate a substantial amount of debt in order to be eligible. The main reason that I would use a card like this is the 0% purchase and balance transfer period. The 15 month period with 0% interest is a tempting offer. The 3% balance transfer fee seems to be comparable with rates of competitors. All in all, this is a tempting card offer for an avid traveler who will use the points, or for anybody who needs to shuffle balances around and doesn’t want to pay interest.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The American Express Serve card sounds like it would be a useful card to have for someone who is just starting out in learning how to manage their money. As opposed to other reloadable prepaid cards, this one doesn't have a monthly fee. In the past I have used cards such as a Greendot, which offered awful terms, conditions, and limits on what I could and could not do. All of these limits ultimately ended up only taking more and more money off of my card, and that is something which is easily avoidable with a card as reliable and honest as the American Express Serve card. Also, having access to free customer service both live and via the internet is a priceless asset which assures the consumer that if there is ever any question about their account which comes to mind, help can be reached at any hour of the day or night.

For most people, theres no real reason to get a Platinum Card from American Express. Unlike, say the Chase Freedom card many people use, few people will even be able to qualify to get one of these cards, and being rejected will just lower your credit score. There's no "preset spending limit" but that's mostly a lie, as they will reject purchases they feel you don't have the ability to pay back, based on the info you gave. So there's no limit but you can't make large purchases, so really there is a limit. Then you have to pay it off in full that month, so even if you wanted to make a medium sized purchase you wouldn't be able to stretch the impact over a few months. Additionally, there's a $450 fee every year. End of the day, this is the perfect credit card....for people that don't need a credit card. It's a status symbol that no one else cares about. Don't bother with this card.
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: When I started college I needed a card to build my credit as well as keep me responsible. This card is great for that! The fact that you have to pay your full balance every month really helps to keep me responsible and lessens the risk that I will make purchases that I will later regret. Not having a monthly fee is really nice too. After the first year the fee is still minimal.

This has been a pretty good card for me. I liked the rewards plan. Their website was easy to use to check my balance and pay my bill. My experience was just make sure that you make your payments on time because they did not hesitate to jack my rate up to the penalty APR when I was late once. This was my fault that I was late, and otherwise I think the card has been very good. The card is accepted everywhere I have tried to use it. I also like to go to concerts with my wife frequently so I use this card to buy tickets through ticketmaster and as part of being a holder of this card I am sometimes given early access to tickets.

The American Express Prepaid Card is great if you need a prepaid card but DON'T have direct deposit. The alternative American Express cards like Serve and Bluebird can be completely free if you have direct deposit, but costly if you don't. This card will only charge you a fee if you make more than one ATM withdrawal a month. The nice thing about this card is that if you use it enough you might get invited to sign up for a normal AMEX card which you can use to start building up your credit. They don't report your activity to the 3 major credit agencies, but for a card with very few charges this is a good first step towards that.

The American Express Green Card is another travel related card from American Express that has subpar benefits. For a whopping $95 annual fee you get 2% on travel. It's ridiculously low compared to what other credit cards offer on travel. You can only redeem the points on travel related purchases, and if you transfer your points to other rewards programs you're going to get less than 1% back after the conversion. You have to pay off your balance every single month too, so it's not really a credit card. And on top of all that, this travel focused rewards card charges a 2.7% foreign transaction fee! Stay clear of this one.

The Blue American Express Credit Card is a good card to have if you like to spend your rewards on travel, but nothing else. With no annual fee you can keep this card in your wallet and use it for anything and get the standard 1% back or 2% back on travel, but keep in mind there are other cards that will get you much more than 2% back on travel. The nice thing about this card rather than other AMEX travel cards is that you don't have to use your points on travel, you can spend them on gift cards too. Sometimes it's nice to have an AMEX card for those places that only take AMEX, and with no annual fee I can justify keeping it around for that reason only.

The American Express Serve card is one of the best prepaid cards I've seen. Mainly because this is the only prepaid card I've seen that actually gives you a cash bonus for signing up! $50 is better than nothing, and if you have direct deposit there are no annual fees that are going to slowly take that $50 away from you. On top of that, you get all the perks of being an AMEX member, including being able to take advantage of Small Business Saturday which is another free $25 every year. If you need a prepaid card consider getting this card or something like Walmart's Bluebird card which also uses the American Express network with very little fees.

This is pretty decent for an American Express card. It's nice to have an AMEX card that doesn't come with an annual fee, but the rewards they offer are below average. This is because the rewards you earn can only be used toward a statement credit towards travel. I personally don't travel that much, so I haven't been able to redeem any rewards using my Blue Sky card. But it's good to have in your wallet because every once in awhile I'll come across a store that only accepts American Express, and I can at least start slowly building to that eventual $100 statement credit.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: While most cards that come with annual fees have pretty average rewards, the American Express Blue Cash Preferred card has some really nice rewards that might be worth the $75/yr they are asking. For starters, you get 6% back on supermarkets with a cap of $6000 every year. That's about $500 a month in groceries, which I don't even come close to spending. Plus 3% back on gas stations and some department stores. The grocery perk alone is enough to justify this card, but if you spend much more than 6K per year you might not be getting the best bang for your buck with this card.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I can only recommend the HIltons Credit Card if you are really big on travel. The point system is kind of confusing to me because you can't use it for straight up cash back. You get these HHonors points which are good for pretty much everything except cash back. You can use them towards rooms at a Hilton hotel, or exchange them for other points programs such as frequent flyer miles for example. So the biggest bang for your buck depends on how you'll use the points, since hotel room prices can vary during the year you might be better off using a regular credit card and using your points for money off your statement.

I really love the American Express Prepaid Card. Unlike many other cards, there are no fees. This is really helpful because as you use your card for more and more time, the fees add up to hundreds of dollars that can be used on other things. I usually use the Netspend card, which has a very high fee of $10. If you get direct deposit, it goes down to $5, but it still adds up to a lot of money over time. I love the fact that the American Express Prepaid off the freedom to deposit a high amount of money onto the card. I look forward to using this card in the near future.

Since I live in Texas, I drive a lot. I love the AMEX blue Cash Preferred because of the 3% cash back whenever I get cash. It's almost like making money back whenever I buy gas, which makes purchasing cash slightly less depressing. Although there is an annual fee of $75, I easily make this back in more when shopping for gas, groceries, and pretty much everything else. I usually make enough back on Christmas presents to get myself a little something something! The card is also virtually accepted everywhere, so I've never had any problems using it. American Express is also pretty aggressive when it comes to fraud or abnormal transactions, so i feel very safe using this card almost anywhere.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: I would not recommend the American Express Green Card for several reasons. The main benefit you get with this card is 2% back on travel and 1% on everything else, but the card comes with a $95 annual fee. For comparison, the Capital One Venture card has a much lower annual fee an 2% back on everything. Plus, this card must be paid off in full every single month. Now while I've never paid a finance charge in my life, it's something to keep in mind if you ever need to use it as a credit card. The subpar benefits combined with a steep annual fee cannot let me recommend it to anyone when there are better alternatives out there.

American Express's Blue Credit Card looks to be a great card in comparisons to a lot of other cards out there. American Express is a very reputable company and that is reflected here, for every dollar you spend you get a point, and double if you buy online, and even better, your points never expire! You can earn an unlimited amount of points and spend those points on tons of different things you can choose from either; merchandise, gift cards, or transfer them directly to different airlines and hotels for instant transactions. American Express has some offers similar to cards I have had in the past, one of which is the PayPal CC and that gives you unlimited points to collect and spend however you wish, if you like to splurge on the occasional big purchases this is great as it has no annual fee so you wont be charged, and for those purchases you make money back, its a win win scenario!

The American Express Prepaid Card is a decent option for a prepaid card. No monthly fees, free direct deposit, and one free ATM withdrawal per month are all great benefits that not all prepaid cards offer. No activation fee, either. Your money stays yours for the most part. The $2500 or $5000 limit is a bit frustrating and you'd better make that one ATM withdrawal count unless you want to get hit with fees because it's $2 per transaction after that. At least they allow you one free, most cards don't. And there aren't fees to use it with a PIN or signature for purchases. There might be a better card out there though because American Express still isn't accepted at as many places as Visa and Mastercard are.

I love my AMEX Blue Cash Preferred. The card gives 6% back on groceries (up to $6,000/year, then 1% back after that), 3% back on gas (unlimited), and 1% back on everything else. You will have to do the math to see if the $75 annual fee will work out for you, because the regular Blue Cash card has no annual fee but only gives back 3% for groceries, 2% for gas, and 1% for everything else. I haven't had any issues with the card, so I can only speak about their initial customer service when I signed up. They were very friendly and I told them I was in a hurry and they expedited the process. If you prefer the "rotating categories" of cash back on other types of cards, this might not be for you. However, if you like to get the highest general cash back then this is the card.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The American Express Gold Card is similar to other credit cards like the Visa Black card. It has a huge annual fee for those with excellent credit, where the only reason to have it is if you can really take advantage of the benefits it offer which usually go along with a high class lifestyle. Things like hotel credits when you stay at Gold Crown hotels, baggage insurance plans, and other travel benefits. I personally think your better off getting a travel specific card if you travel a lot to maximize your cash back or avoid foreign transaction fees. With this card's 2.7% foreign transaction fee you are better off using the Capital One Venture Card.

The Blue Sky from American Express card looks like a pretty blah travel card, that's only helpful if you really want an American Express card. The intro period is pretty long, which is good because the interest rate after is nothing to write home about. There's no annual fee, which is decently rare for an American Express card. But the bonus system isn't that great. Getting 7500 points for $1000 worth of purchases is a nice jumpstart of 10% cash back that you have to use for travel, but after that the rate is really unfavorable and behind a lot of competitive cards like the Chase Freedom Visa or even the Amazon card. Even if you're a frequent traveler, there's better ways out there to get more return on your purchases. If you know you're about to buy a travel ticket, get this, spend $1000, get $100 bucks off, but don't pull this out very often afterwards.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The Hilton Credit Card by American Express is a pretty good card, especially for travelers. My family and I travel a lot, so this is a great card for us. I was able to get a lot of points with it. I have a few AMEX credit cards, and time and time again I see why I get their cards. The rewards are great, customer service is excellent, and fees are relatively low compared to other cards. The one and only problem I tend to have with them is that they aren't accepted everywhere. Ever since getting this card we've been staying at the Hilton, which is a much nicer hotel than I originally thought. I've earned a ton of bonus points which has made me happy! Get this card if you're a traveler!

The American Express Save Card is a nice prepaid card. No monthly or activation fees. This will attract many people. Cancellation fees are free as well which is great if you only want this for a limited amount of time. I also like American Express' customer service, they tend to be very helpful when I have a problem with them. Although I prefer credit cards, I think this is the way to go if you want to get a good prepaid card with low fees. The main problem with this card is that American Express is not taken at all places, so some places will deny you if you try to use the card.

The Blue Card preferred by American Express is a great card. How many people shop at supermarkets? Everyone. Everyone can benefit from the great deal that they give, giving 6% cash back. They also give you money back for gas which is nice. The $150 bonus is nice too. There really isn't anything bad about this card. The worst things about it pretty much compare the same to other cards. APR is pretty average, as are the other rates. I will be sticking to this card for a while. The amount of grocery shopping I do makes it so worth having. I guess one con is that not everyone accepts American Express.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The Blue from American Express Credit Card is definitely a card to have in your wallet. Some places only accept American Express like CostCo, and this card will allow you to take advantage of special American Express promotions like small business Saturday! The rewards are basic at only 1% back on everyday purchases, 2% on travel. But what is great about this American Express card is that is has no annual fee. It's not a card to use for your every day purchases, but at those places that only accept American Express you could be earning rewards that you otherwise couldn't get with cash.

The American Express Green Card sounds like a great card to use if you are ok with paying the balance in full each month. The great news is that you eliminate interest charges that way. The late fee charges are actually very reasonable compared to other cards I have had in the past. My Bank of America Visa charges $65 for a late fee. It sounds great not to have any blackout dates on travel points. My current card has so many blackout dates that I have to work around them while traveling. The $95 annual fee is pretty steep compared to other cards I have carried but the benefits may be worth it.

Most of us will never be able to apply for the American Express Platinum Card, as it is with people with superior credit and a lot of money to spend. On paper it might seem crazy, with a $450 annual fee and needing to pay your balance in full every month, but the true benefit with this card is no credit limit. I would assume that if you need to have a credit card with no credit limit, then you can afford the $450 annual fee which they are asking for. This card ranks up there with the Visa Black card as a credit card only rich folks can afford to have in their wallet
department: The Platinum Card® from American Express

content: I am very impressed with the American Express Gold Card! I really think the rewards and points are great and it is awesome to be rewarded while using a card. The fact that there is no interest rate is attractive although you must pay your balance in full at the end of the month. I do like that option though and I wish my current card Capital One were more like this but I am rebuilding my credit. Eventually I think I will go for the American Express because of the perks. My only worry is making sure I budget properly so I could pay off the bill at the end of the month. No annual in the first year which is great but second year it becomes a $125 annual fee which is quite steep, but if you can make sure your rewards outweigh the cost well then I think its worth it for sure! I have heard great things about the customer service which is also a huge plus. I would worry that I may overspend to try and accumulate rewards and points but that is not a fault with a card that is more to do with myself personally. So I think definitely the risks and costs should be thought about before you decide on this card.

It's very important to have an American Express card in your wallet, and this is the one you should have. The nice thing about the Blue Sky Credit Card from American Express is that it has no annual fee, yet still has rewards! Usually American Express has some sort of annual fee associated with it, but not with this card. On top of that you get the same fraud protection, member benefits and other perks that you would with any other American Express card. For example, I have been registering my card every year for Small Business Saturday which gives you a free $25 credit when you spend $25 at a small business.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: I got the Blue Sky from American Express card last year and have been very satisfied with it. I wanted an American Express card because I knew the customer support was great and wanted to protect my purchases with the extended warranty program on everything you buy. I also did not want to pay a fee. I get about 1.33% cashback on everything as long as I redeem it for travel rewards. This is my best cashback offer and I buy everything on this card that is not getting a 5% promo on it's category on my Chase Freedom card. The only negative thing is that you redeem in chunks of $100 and sometimes I do not have a $100 related travel purchase on my statement.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: The Hilton Credit Card looks like a good idea for anybody who is constantly visiting places, whether it is locally, to another town for family and vacation or also for business whether it is domestically or internationally. You receive a base amount of 3 points anywhere but whenever you buy food and gas at both grocery stores, gas stations and restaurants you get points at 5 points for every dollar spent. Whenever you make a purchase through the Hilton company you make on average 7 points per every dollar that you spend. It seems that if you use this card any time that you travel you will easily be able to spend at least $750 in a year and be able to get a bonus of 40,000 points and if you're traveling and spending more frequently (whether for business or personal use) you'll probably be able to spend $20,000 and achieve Gold Status. This is definitely recommended if you're a person that's regularly on the-go whether it's locally or out of town.

American Express' Blue Cash Preferred card is definitely one of the better cash back credit cards to look at. The annual fee is not cheap at $75, but the 6% cash back at grocery stores is extremely high compared to similar cards. If you have a large family or simply buy a lot of groceries, you could make the annual fee back in a few months of shopping. The 3% back at gas stations should also be attractive to those with long commutes. The 1% cash back on all purchases is pretty standard, so if you don't spend a lot at grocery stores and gas stations you might be better off with a different card. However, the intro period of 15 months with 0% APR is a great deal for anyone who wants to finance some large purchases in the near future.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The American Express Serve card is pretty great if you need a prepaid card to handle your direct deposits. The way this card shines as opposed to other prepaid cards is that there is no activation fee, cancellation fee, or inactivity fee. The only fee most people will ever see is the $2 charge for out of network ATM withdraws, but that fee is waived as long as you have direct deposit set up. On top of that, American Express has phenomenal customer service, and you get the same quality of fraud protection as if you had a regular American Express credit card that usually comes with an annual fee.

The Blue Sky from American Express card has no annual fee! That's almost always the first thing I look for when I am looking into credit cards. It seems to me that if you are already spending money with a card then you shouldn't have to pay even more each year. The initial bonus for this card seems pretty nice. It's in point though unlike the Chase Freedom card which gives cash as an initial bonus. The interest rate seems typical to any other card out there, but the cash advance rate seems pretty steep. The best part is that you can keep earning bonus points to put toward travel which is great. Overall this is not a bad card but if you’re looking for a good travel rewards card take a look at the Southwest card. It has better bonuses.
department: Blue Sky from American Express® Card

content: I love my SkyMiles card for a lot of reasons. It's helping me build my credit for one thing but more importantly I gain miles for every purchase. I've used the miles to make several trips and couldn't have made them without the 30,000 bonus miles you receive when you first sign up for the card. Another perk is one FREE checked bag for everyone in your party (your AMEX card must be used to book reservation). The interest rates aren't bad either though I am a very responsible spender :) Getting approved for this card was simple and I recommend it to anyone who likes to travel or spend money! I wish there were other rewards associated with this card but so far I can't really complain.
department: Delta SkyMiles® Gold American Express Card

content: The Blue Cash Everyday Card from American Express is an excellent balance transfer credit card. With only a 3% fee and 0% for 15 months on the balance, its pretty high up there with the other balance transfer cards. Add to that the rewards program and the initial sign up bonus, you've got yourself a pretty snazzy card! The 0% APR for 15 months is pretty helpful as well.
department: Blue Cash Everyday® Card from American Express

content: The American Express Prepaid Card is very nice prepaid card. With absolutely no recurring fees, this beats a lot of other prepaid cards offered out there. One hug drawback, however, is that they only offer one measly ATM withdrawal per month. Then, you need to pay $2 for every withdrawal afterwards. So if you get this card, it would be smart to keep half of your money in cash, and half in the card so you don't have to withdraw too many times. A good perk about this card is that you may receive more offers from American Express if you have a nice record. This card is also good for teaching young teens to learn how to manage money.

The Blue Cash Preferred American Express Credit Card is undoubtedly the best cash back credit card you can get. The incredible 6% cash back for grocery shopping is unmatched by any other credit card out there. The initial sign-up bonus is also pretty nice; $150 for spending $1,000. If you use this for groceries, you should easily reach that within the given time frame. This also has a whopping 3% cashback on gas, which is pretty good considering the 6% groceries already. This is a very good main spending card. With 0% APR for 15 months, there's nothing bad at ALL with this card. This is a must have if you can get it.
department: Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express

content: The Hilton Credit Card is a fantastic card for frequent travelers. I have family members that live in various parts of the US, and several that live outside of it. This card has helped me earn Hilton points pretty quickly and moved me up from Hilton Silver status to Gold status. I have already generated enough points to receive several free nights at Hilton Hotels. I have had this card for over 5 years and I have been extremely happy using it. I have several other credit cards, but this is the one I almost always use. I definitely recommend this credit card for anyone that travels frequently.

The American Express Green Card is a decent choice if you're looking for a charge card. I think that the annual fee is slightly high, but the late fees are competitive with similar charge cards such as Discover. Paying your balance at the end of each billing period means you'll need to still be very responsible with your spending, but then there is no interest to worry about. The financial tools they offer like managing your account online, and the points incentive program make this card worth checking out. You can even use your points to pay for travel expenses.

The Blue from American Express Credit Card is sweet! The initial sign-up bonus is pretty awesome for those that want to churn credit cards but don't spend too much.
